There are no startup fees like a lot of other secured credit cards, and only an annual fee of $29. The minimum amount needed to secure the card is $200, which is much lower than other cards that can require a $500 deposit for a secured account. There is also a positive in that you can interest on whatever money you put down, and you can get a regular unsecured credit card after only 18 months. The interest rate for purchases is 18.24%, which is competitive among secured cards, and can jump up to almost 30% if paid late, which is standard among any credit card. In the end, I would recommend this secured card only if you have bad credit or no credit and need help in rebuilding it.

name: Frank Bieniek
review: I have tremendously enjoyed using Citibank and I really like their service.  I was talking to a few people on the phone and they were really helpful with my student loans.  They made sure to tell me how much the interest of the bank is, and they also helped me sort out my loans.  I was really appreciative for what they done.  I would highly recommend it to anyone and I would always give them another shot.  I have already recommended this service to my friends and family and they are thrilled to be using this service and this bank account.

name: Veronica
review: I absolutely love citibank! Before them, I was with TD. TD always gave me hoops to go through, on a constant basis. They would randomly shut my account off, have terrible glitches, and bad customer support. I decided on Citibank due to the convenience of locations, and I couldn't be happier. All of their branches are extremely clean and modern; their customer support has ALWAYS been extremely helpful whenever I needed them. They've even waived overdraft fees for me when I've run into issues. Their interest on Savings isn't that high (none of the banks have high interest, though), but I do feel safe and secure leaving my money with them. I would highly recommend this bank!

name: Jeremy Arotsky
review: This card seems like a very good deal - five points on books, movies, and music. Those are some pretty common and broad categories, so it seems like it would be relatively easy to earn those extra bonus points. That would mean that if I bought a movie at say $25, I would earn 125 Thank You points. The interest rate seems good too, plus it comes with a 0% APR initial promotion. This may have recently been changed to the Simplicity card recently however, I'm not sure if they're still giving out the Forward.

name: Shanae LaVelle
review: Finding a credit card that works well for your lifestyle can be challenging, even more so when it comes to credit cards available from gas stations. While there are many different credit cards available with petroleum companies all over the US, the only way of efficiently use the credit card offer is to use the gasoline offered by the company. If you frequently fuel up at any Sunoco, the Sunoco Credit Card is could be a great option for you. It offers 3 ThankYou points per dollar on your first and second gas purchases but turns to 10 points per dollar after the third gas purchase. This card will only be effective for the user if they make several gasoline purchases a month. You might only buy gas once or twice a month currently, but in order to get the best deal from this card, I would suggest filling a partial tank a few times early on so you can get to the 10 points/dollar. The annual rate is variable but is offered at 16.999% according to initial documentation. No monthly fees, which is a bonus as well. Again, this may not be the best option for your lifestyle, but if you want to get the most out of you local Sunoco fuel, this card may be the way to go.

name: Alex Steven
review: The Citi Forward Card for college students is great for me (a college student). The thank you points are very nice and easy to obtain. There are no hidden fees with this card, and APR is pretty low compared to other cards. Overall I'm happy with this card, but it does lose a point for penalty APR being pretty high at 30%.

name: Jeremy Arotsky
review: Citi Diamond Preferred is a card that is basically built specifically for balance transfers. This card comes with a pretty 18 month 0% APR intro rate for both purchases and balance transfers, that's longer than most cards which usually only have a year. It also has other perks such as the concierge service and Private Pass for your favorite shows. The only thing this card lacks is a viable rewards service, though you can still gain points from certain purchases toward discounts.

name: Stephen Marth
review: I am really pleased with the Citi Forward card. The interest rate for the card is very low which you do not see any more these days. It offers a great point program and if you take advantage of it in the time frame they offer for the 10,000 bonus point offer, you can really make it worth your while. The card also offers a great balance transfer rate. Citi's customer service is also great and I have never had any issues with them. The only problem I would have with the card is the cash advance rate, which is quite high. Otherwise I love this card and I highly suggest that you sign up for it when able!

name: Adam
review: I've been working on rebuilding my credit over the past 18 months and this card has been very helpful in doing so.  I made a deposit of $300 and the annual fee is only $29, which seems to be pretty standard for secured credit cards.  The APR is pretty low compared to the other card I have at 14.99%.  I'm not sure how their customer service department is, but only because I've never had to call them - which to me means they've been great.  I haven't gotten any random fees or charges or anything.  The only downside is that it takes a minimum of 18 months to convert the secured card into a "real" credit card, but as long as I'm building credit I'm okay with that.

name: Pascal Jacobs
review: Like many store cards, the Radio Shack credit card has a pretty high APR at 28.99%. In my experience you can often buy electronics cheaper at other retailers like Target and Sears, which have store cards with APR's of around 22 and 25 respectively. I don't think the initial bonus of a 10% discount merits such a high APR on the Radio Shack card. What I think redeems this card to a large extent is the financing plan the store offers. If you spend at least $150, you have 6 months of no interest if you pay your balance in full, and if you spend $300 or more, then you have a whole year. That is actually a good deal if you plan on making a big purchase. If you can't avoid the high APR, however, I would just suggest using your regular credit card if you must.

name: Milli Cash
review: I like that you can earn 4 points for every dollar  you spend online or at Brooks Brothers stores. I also like that you can earn 1 point for every dollar spent wherever MasterCard is accepted. Another plus is you get 15% off your first Brooks Brothers purchase. Brooks Brother have different rewards like one is you receive a $20 reward card automatically for every 2000 points you earn. I do not like the rates on this card. 14% - 21% That's a lot of interest. Unlike my Discover card Brooks Brothers have more rewards you can win from. Also the grace period on my Discover card was 7 days. But on the Brooks Brothers Card it is 23 days. That is also a plus.

name: Alex Steven
review: The AT&T  Credit Card is a decent card. I like the no annual fee, as many cards have annual fees nowadays. I also like the rewards. Getting up to $350 per year is great. Since I use AT&T as my cellular phone line, this is great for me. Those $200 phones every 2 years are expensive. As with other cards, if you don't have AT&T, I'd say not to get this card, as APR is just average. But if you use AT&T frequently, then definitely consider it! I also advice that if you're just a light AT&T customer, and don't plan to use them extremely frequently,also look for another card. Only use this if you use AT&T a lot!

name: Andrea Leonard Targonski
review: We originally applied for the Sears store credit card to purchase a patio set, because there was an extra discount for opening the card. We found out then that Sears consistently has special cardholder discounts, so you can use the card to get the discount and then pay it off right away. The interest rate is not ridiculous, considering it's a store card, but it doesn't really matter to us because we don't carry a balance on credit cards. I also like that the card can be used at Kmart and the Sears Portrait Studio. While we never had to use it, the 0% liability on fraudulent purchases is reassuring.

name: Thomas Burke
review: I have an Amex card but it looks pretty good for one reason. Amex One card gives 1 percent back, but the LL Bean one is on the Visa network which everyone accepts. I've had smaller places like corner stores that won't take Amex because their merchant rates are higher. Cash advance rate is way high for things like international travel, between that and currency exchange fees you'd have to be in a bad emergency to use that part if you didn't pay in full every month. I assume that the regular rate varies based on credit score, but 19.99 percent is really high. I guess most cards are high now, but I wouldn't want to carry a balance with this for very long.

name: Jeremy Arotsky
review: The rewards attached to this card are very travel oriented obviously, being through Expedia, so if you're a traveler this could be a card for you. It's through Citi, so you earn Thank You points. Their reward program isn't my favorite (I'm a fan of Chase's Ultimate Rewards), but for what it is it does earn them pretty well. Two points on Expedia, one everywhere else - it could be better, but it's not the worst. You also have access to the perks of World MasterCard and Citi - no spending limit, Private Pass, etc. also come with this card.

name: Pascal Jacobs
review: The Tire Kingdom store card looks like it would be nice to own in case you need new tires and don't have the money right away. The APR is pretty high at 28.95%, but they do offer no interest deals for 12 months($799 minimum purchase) and 6 months($199 at least) if paid in full. This can be a life saver if you don't have the money and you have an emergency with your car. The Goodyear store card has an APR of 28.99 %, but doesn't have  "no interest" deals like Tire Kingdom. That is a lot of interest to pay and I don't really see many perks to make the card with it. You would be better off just using a regular card with a lower APR.

name: Pascal Jacobs
review: The Citi Secured Credit card looks like a pretty good way to improve your credit score. Your credit line is dictated by the amount of money you deposit in a CD-200-5000 dollars. Your performance is then reported to credit bureaus. Your deposit will earn interest of 1%. This all seems like a good way to improve your credit and work your way up to better credit cards. What I don't like is the APR of 18.24%. That is fairly high and for someone with already bad credit, it may cause difficulties.  With an APR of 14.99%, the First Platinum Select secured credit card is a little more reasonable, but the minimum deposit is 300 dollars. Also, its annual fee is 10 dollars more at 39 dollars. I think if you are careful, either card will help you improve your credit.

name: Dan G
review: The Staples Store credit card is yet another store card, but this offers some decent incentive to use. There are no fees for cash advances which is always nice, and you get automatically enrolled into Staples Rewards program where you get 5% back on all items!! Some downsides of the card is that it has a pretty steep interest rate at 28% which can deter some people from trying it. I suggest trying a different card if you are not one who shops at Staples to often, A card I would suggest is the Amazon CC, you get rewards on every purchase, and has great rates. Overall the Staples card is not bad, and is actually above average, if you are a fan of the store give it a shot.

name: Veronica
review: I signed up for a checking account through Citibank a year ago. As a student, I was entitled to the students checking account, which meant I don't have to have a set amount of money in my account monthly, a major plus for me. They have been such a wonderful bank to do business with. I over drafted a couple of times, and after explaining my situation to them, they have reversed the fees. I am able to take my money out of my account at my convenience, either at their branch or at a local 7-11. They always make sure to send alerts if something seems to be "off" on my account, and their customer service has been superb. I would highly recommend Citibank for your checking account needs.

name: Bela Kalinova
review: This card has been really helpful to me as I am currently doing many home projects. IT was worth it to sign up and see what rewards I could get by using the Home Depot Store Card. There is a high interest rate of 17.99 percent, but that is not to outweigh the good sides this card has to offer. It will help you have an easier shopping experience. It is very useful to those of you who enjoy the home depot's low pricing. I would recommend this to anyone who shops here. Although I do not know of any rewards program, I still enjoy having this card at my disposal.

name: abigail lee
review: The shell credit card is just alright. It is good if you go to shell a lot, then you'll save 20 cents per gallon. It does add up, but it takes a while before you can see a good amount of savings. Other credit card companies like Discover and Bank of America gives 3-5% cash back when you use those credit cards at the pump. It just depends on what you need this credit card for. Shell does not always have the cheapest gas price, but they have good quality gas. A better gas credit card would be the costco american express credit card.

name: Chris No
review: I like this card because I'm a technology guy anything new in that field I'm looking to buy. I often go into Best Buy stores and check out their new stuff. This card is pretty amazing and fits someone like myself. They have 24 month financing for TV's which was pretty much the thing I was looking at. The Financing rate is at a good rate 11.9% for the first 48 months. One thing I also like about this card is the fact that you get bonus points when you purchase a certain amount dollar wise. The base earn is 1 point / $1 but you can get all the way up to 2.5 points / $1. One bad thing is there is late penalty's which is 35 dollars. Another good thing is you get  a $5 reward certificate for every 250 points earned which I think is good you spend and the company rewards you more, it's something Best Buy doesn't have to do, they are a good company.

name: Dan Diciaula
review: I use the card a lot for business.  The apr is a little high, but that's pretty standard for office supply stores.  I pay the balance off in full each month so it's not a big deal.  It's much more convenient than carrying cash or putting my purchases on a credit card.  We earn rewards even though we are a small business and get tons of discounts and email coupons.  I also like the fact that it keeps track of our purchases.  Last week I had to re-order ink for our printer and instead of taking the printer apart and trying to figure out which cartridge I just went to office depot and they were able to locate the brand based on my previous purchases.  It's convenient and saves money.

name: jesse
review: The AT&T Credit Card is a really interesting credit card. It has no annual fee. Which something I'm crazy about. You must have a pretty good credit rating if you want to get this card though. This card offer all kind of rewards. The one I like the most is up to 350 dollars toward AT&T products a year. That means you can get your self a new phone every year with this credit card, just by using it. It does not offer an intro rate, which is kind of depressing but the APR is just 14 percent, which is decent. I have the Capital One Venture One Rewards Credit Card. This card is very similar but it offers a 0 percent intro rate for the first year, which is something you can't beat. I would recommend this card to anyone who is a new phone addict. You can really make this credit card work for you.

name: Jane Lill
review: The Brooks Brothers credit card is a convenient option for those who frequent the store and are looking to rack up some rewards with their shopping. It's nice that the card can be used outside Brooks Brothers and you will still earn points, although not nearly as many. The initial bonus isn't anything to scoff at at 15% off your first purchase. The $20 birthday gift is a really nice incentive! Not all store cards offer that sort of annual discount. And depending on how good your credit is, you can actually qualify for a decent interest rate (as low as 14.24%)! This is a low rate compared to most store cards. If you aren't going to be using the card at Brooks Brothers a ton though, I would suggest you look at alternative rewards cards. American Express Blue Cash is a nice alternative, as well as some Discover cards.

name: Lily Yee
review: I am not usually a big fan of store cards unless it is a Macy's or Nordstrom's card. When I went to college, I need to make some purchases and I did not have a car. The closest thing around me was a radioshack. At radioshack, I had to buy a phone, camera and a printer so I got this card. I got this card to get the discount which was not that great. I think I would been better off to not have this card and look for coupons.  The only reason this card is not 1 star because it allows financing. I was able to payoff all my purchases within 4 months. I was not ready to pay interest on purchases especially on Radioshack- the interest rate is too high. Once i paid it off, I closed it immediately. This card was really no good for anything else. Their employees at the store don't really know about the card so whenever I had questions I call the national line.

name: Delano Jones
review: The Expedia Credit Card is a moderately preferable card.  In the past I’ve used the Capital One Journey Student Rewards Credit Card and it has features that better fit my financial needs and goals.  The Expedia Credit Card requires that you have a good or excellent credit rating while the Journey card is for students with restricted or average credit ratings.  Neither of the two cards have an annual fee which is great.  Both cards have cash back reward incentives with Expedia restricting the cardholders earning limit.  The Capital One Journey card does not have a limit on its reward limit.

name: timothy bull
review: I own and operate a small business and the Staples card has been a real lifesaver in helping me keep the business running smoothly. I buy the majority of my supplies at staples and using the card not only gets me a 5% reward back on all purchases it also helps me to keep everything organized business wise with one easy to read monthly statement.. While the APR is higher than I generally like there isn't an annual card fee which evens it out some, I also pay the balance monthly so I don't typically have to worry too much about interest.The staples card is a no-brainer and it's use will grow with my business easily making sure I can keep on top of all my business needs while keeping all my records straight at the same time.

name: Daniel Sales
review: The Staples store card is a pretty basic store credit card. If anyone has had a credit card before then they understand the routine here. About a 28% interest rate late fees and a 25 day grace period are fairly common. But where this card really shines is in it's 5% back on purchases. It is amazing, especially when compared to the Office Depot card that only gives a 1% return. The drawback, though is that Office Depot allows for as low as a 19% interest rate. Where one's Staple's Card will always be at the fixed 27%. As long as the Store Card bill is paid on time however, the amount saved will have been 5 times that of the Office Depot card.

name: timothy bull
review: The Tire Kingdom Store Card is much like other cards in the automotive service industry like Merchants. These cards are great to have in case of an emergency like your car breaking down unexpectedly because on larger purchases they usually give you 6-12 months to pay off the service without interest accruing. For every day type purchases it's better to use cash or another card as the Tire Kingdom Card and others like it have high interest rates attached to them.When you do find you are having car trouble and it looks like it could be costly having a Tire Kingdom card or one like it will definitely be helpful and for that reason I always suggest having a card like this as we all run into unexpected car problems now and again and they usually happen at the worst possible time financially.

name: jesse
review: The Citi Secured Credit Card is an alright card for rebuilding your credit but there are much better secured credit cards out there. This card requires a minimum deposit of 200 dollars and there is an annual fee of 29 dollars. You also must wait 18 months before you can get a regular credit card. I prefer a Bank of America secured credit card. The minimum deposit is 100 dollars and there is no annual fee at all. You can also get a regular credit card in 12 months, which is what I really want. I would recommend this credit card with the disclaimer that there are better deals out there to be had.

name: Aliciadine Oliphant
review: I like the fact that if you are a frequent shopper at LL Bean that you can earn discounts everytime you use the card.  The maximum penalty APR is quite high and the cash advance rate as well. I also love the fact that along with earning at LL Bean you can earn 1% wherever you use your visa. That is huge especially when you are using it at hotels, gas stations, and other retail outlets.  Every penny saved helps. I have a prepaid account now visa which does not offer a lot of these things. I also do not have a discount for the discovery school purchases. If you have a student and want to buy, 10 percent savings can be a big deal.

name: Jonathan Doebly
review: I've had my Staples store card for about a year now and I'm really pleased with it. At first glance I was a little reluctant with such a high interest rate but the cashier told me I would be saving about fifty dollars if I signed up. I did sign up with the intention of canceling it but the next time I went to the store I noticed how many things were on the 5% discount. Almost everything in a staples has the discount if you have your card. The 28 percent interest is high but when you pay it off at the end of the month you just saved a lot money. They also have specials for the card holders all the time. Every couple of months they have buy one bundle of paper and get one free with a limit of ten, great deal. Altogether the interest rate is higher than say my Khols card but you get to use it a lot more and save a little more.

name: Bill Henderson
review: The nicest thing about the Sears Store card is that it is usable at K-Mart stores nationwide.  We've used this card many times for various things, including last-minute Christmas presents when money is tight.  Another nice thing is there is a low payment due so you don't have to pay much month to month.  Obviously, this is also a bad point as you will carry a balance for a long time if you only make the minimum payment and don't pay off the entire balance.  One other issue I have had is that we were signed up for the Credit Insurance, which I believe was $8.95 a month, which can really add up over time.  I'm not sure how we were signed up, but it was easy to cancel.

name: Chris No
review: I like this card because I shop at Home Depot fairly regularly they have very competitive pricing and generally having helping hands throughout the store. The one thing I really dislike about the card is the interest rate it is extremely high 17.99 being the lowest is kind of crazy. Compared to some of my other store cards I do have a 6 month interest free period on all my purchases which is a nice thing to add. I do like the grace period this card offers for late fees which is 25 days that's nice they don't try to penalize you right away. Overall this card is really good and useful for the small purchases I make.

name: William
review: With more and more credit cards offering tailored rewards, the Best Buy Credit Card seems tailored towards the electronics nut. Using it at Best Buy earns you 2 ½ points for every dollar you spend at Best Buy. In addition to the rewards points, every 250 points earns you a $5 rewards certificate that can be used on any store purchase. The interest rate seems to be on par with what other cards offer, but glaringly absent is a grace period, so no matter how quickly you pay off your purchase there’s going to be an interest charge. It offers cash advances at what seems to be a rather high rate of 27.99 percent, or $15, whichever is higher, which makes cash advances from this card rather pricey and something to be avoided. If you do a lot of shopping at Best Buy, this might be a card for you to use strictly at Best Buy, but for regular day-to-day use I think there are better offerings out there to be considered.

name: Julie Johnson
review: As a person who shops for tools often, this card is invaluable to me. My Sears Credit Card is great, as I like to shop around at Sears, Kmart, and even occasionally online, and this card functions great at each one of these places. For a few years I used my everyday card, a Capital One Platinum Card, for my tool purchases at Sears and one day I decided to pick this one up, and it is great for managing my purchases, and having them all in one place. This card has made my tool shopping experience extremely convenient, so much so that I have been purchasing extra tools and giving them as gifts for my friends birthdays, and come Christmas time they will each be getting a nice new ratchet set!

name: Jonathan Doebly
review: As far a bonus cards go this isn't the best one unless you buy your gas at shell. Around here it's the only gas stations in town so the cards really useful for me. The only great thing about this card is the 20 cents a gallon bonus which is 10 cents more the my Chase credit card gives me. I just make sure to pay the balance off at the end of the month and I'm saving 20 cents a gallon by the middle of the month. So far it's made a big difference in my savings and ever little penny helps right now. When I have been hit with interest it's not as bad as most cards. At 24 percent it's slightly lower than most gas cards and the grace period on payments is a lot more lenient. Altogether it's a good card if you buy at a Shell station.

name: Alexander Tsagamilis
review: I have been a customer of Citibank for more than 20 years. In general the bank has always treated me well and tried to fulfill all my needs from time to time in the most expedient way despite the highly regulated environment it operates in (which seems to be increasing over time). I have had the same experience while conducting business with Citi from abroad. Actually, in some ways their service abroad appears to be even better given the level of service of some of the local/regional banks.The one thing that does though annoy me is the bank's traditional higher fees. I believe this to be historically true from my experience. All sorts of transactions conducted with them over the years carried high fees compared to the competition (except the online ones to be fair). Is it really necessary to still charge me $20 per month if my Checking account is below c.$2,000? Does it cost the bank that much? Not in line with their very good customer service...Also, when I enter one of their branches the pressure to buy into one of their products (irrelevant with the reason/purpose I walked in the bank) has become extremely annoying. I understand the employees have "orders" to sell as much as possible, but I think their style and demeanor has become extremely aggressive!...Lighten up friends. Nobody responds favorably when he/she feels that pressured, actually leading to the opposite effect of not wanting to come back due to fear of pressure!...All in all though I do give them good marks overall and I do recommend them doing business both in the US and definitely abroad.

name: robert mack
review: The Citi Forward Card for College Students is a decent card for student that have limited credit history. I have used it for about 6 months so far and have not had any problems. The intro rate of 0% is helpful and even after the introduction period the interest rate is not that high.The cash advance feature is very helpful in cases of emergency and it has already gotten me out of one jam when I had car troubles! The interest rate on the loan feature is at around the normal range as other cards. This card is great for all students who are looking to build their credit.

name: Joy Whetstone
review: The Sunoco Credit card is a great tool for busy adults.  While other cards in my wallet use up their points and discounts with one or two gas purchases, the Sunoco card adds up the points and discounts as I keep filling my tank throughout the month.  No buying over priced groceries at Kroger to earn the points!  I like the features of it being a regular Credit card, too, and the option to use it for all my other purchases.  With no annual fees, and a twenty-five day grace period, this is an excellent card for fuel purchase for business travel, too. Gas purchases are a 'necessary evil' for most Americans, and it is just nice to get a little reward for trying to be economical.

name: Dolores Severance
review: The Citi Forward card is a good card as far as the interest rates and the annual fee are concerned. The rates seem to be low unlike other cards. Even the Sony card from Capital One or NFL card do not offer rates quite as low as the Citi Forward card. (they start at 13.99 or 14.99%). As far as the rewards go the Sony card only gives you 5000 bonus points. The NFL card gives you 10,000 bonus points. All of these cards offer you a chance to earn extra points but unlike the other two, the Citi Forward card allows you to earn extra points on things that you would purchase more often like books or movies (unlike purchases from the NFL shop or the Sony shop. I like the no annual fee and low interest rates but I don't like the rewards program. You can't redeem the 10,000 reward points until you make $650 in purchases and sign up for paperless statements in the first 3 months. Although that's not hard to do, who wants to put that much on their card right away. I think I would rather get back a % off of my statement. I also like the intro rate of 0% for the first 12 months.

name: Rob Doe
review: The Citi Diamond Preferred Card is a great credit card. It's probably my favorite one I've seen in a while. The  0% Intro APR on Balance Transfers and Purchases for 18 months is just awesome. I would never choose a card with an annual fee I don't understand why anyone would choose a card with an annual fee when there are cards this great out there with no annual fee. The 24/7 concierge service has come in handy more than once, its an amazing feature. Also, after the 18 month 0% APR the 11.99% - 21.99% really isn't bad either if you ask me. All in all i give this card a thumbs up any one in the market for a new card should really give this one a good consideration.

name: jesse
review: I love my Citi Simplicity Card. It is my favorite card out of all of them. It doesn't offer cash back or points or anything. It is just like the name says. It simple. No late fees! No penalty fees! No annual fees! No overdraft fees! What could be better when you sometimes forget to pay your bill. With a 0% APR for the first 18 months, what could be better. It does bump up to 12.99 APR but that is not that high for a credit card. I would recommend this card to anyone. The name says it all. Simplicity!

name: AviRose Anthony
review: I absolutely love my Citi Simplicity Card. Unless someone has carried this card as I have, it is hard to judge just how well put together it is. This is the only credit card that I own. Every feature of it absolutely benefits me. I never feel like I have been "had" when I get my monthly statements. I love my 0% for 18 months and zero late fees. I feel that these 2 factors are what drew me to the card in the first place. Citi Bank does really well with how they create their credit cards for consumers, but they did exceptionally well with this one in particular, in my opinion.

name: Jordan Webb
review: The Staples Store Card is a fairly standard store credit card that could be relatively beneficial to individuals or business that spend frequently on office supplies. The standard, flat rate of 5% cash back is a pretty nice reward. However, this comes at a big price, as there is a 28% interest rate that cannot be changed. This card is pretty nice though, since it can be linked to a Staples Rewards program pretty easily, so that even more benefits can be earned! The online statements and account management is rare for a store card and a very nice feature.

name: Jordan Webb
review: The Tire Kingdom Store Card could be worth it if you have a big purchase coming up from the company! The $50 initial card bonus is pretty nice, and it’s great that you can avoid interest on all purchases if paid within a certain amount of months! This comes at a big gamble, however, because when you do have to pay interest it’s a whopping 29%, which is absolutely huge! If you can afford to take a huge hit if you can’t pay off your purchases on time, then consider this card, otherwise stay away from this huge interest rate.

name: Jordan Webb
review: The L.L Bean Credit Card is a fairly basic store rewards card that doesn’t really stand out in any way. The 1% base rewards back with a potential to earn 3% is pretty standard for a store card and may be useful if the owner frequently goes to L.L. Bean. The interest rate is also a bit lower compared to other store cards, so that is a great benefit of this one. This card also entitles you to a lot of coupons, perfect for someone looking for good deals or bargains! All in all, this card is worth a shot if you go here a lot.

name: Jordan Webb
review: The Expedia Credit Card is perfect for someone who is always on the go! The rewards program is pretty great, especially the initial $50 credit; however, you really need to be able to use it frequently in order to fully take advantage of the rewards program. If you frequently use Expedia for hotel or flights, this can save you some serious cash on things you would normally spend on! However, I wouldn’t recommend using the card for anything other than the site, as the interest rate is pretty mediocre if not high for this type of card and there is no introductory rate offered.

name: Nia Lochlain
review: This is a slightly different take on a secured credit card, where instead of making a simple deposit you are required to invest in a certificate of deposit. This has some ups and downs, since a certificate of deposit can be beneficial in the long term with a 1% interest rate generating some extra income on the deposit. Unfortunately, a certificate of deposit can’t be accessed until the end of an interest cycle, which is typically a set amount of time like a year. If money is tight and you ever need to access the money, there could be penalties involved, which is always a tough decision to make. Aside from that, this card is a really great way to instantly get a card with a very high credit limit. If your credit score isn't very good, getting a high credit limit is generally a long and expensive process, so this is a pretty useful type of credit card to get. I think the certificate of deposit can be a downside only if money is tight; otherwise it can be a great benefit since it offers competitive interest rates and is a fast way to boost the credit limit of the card.

name: Joseph Fryer
review: I have had the Best Buy store credit card for about three years or so now. The interest rate is honestly not great by any means, (25%, ouch) but that  sincerely doesn’t matter, as like must store cards, you get X amount of months interest free, with the amount of months depending on the initial amount you spend.  Like any other credit situation, just be sure that if you do use this card with that promotion, PAY OFF THE CARD in the allotted time, because a 25% interest rate even on small amounts will pack quite a punch if you’re not careful. Personally, I’ve never had this problem, as I paid the card off within the timeframe, so for me, the Best Buy store card has been great.

name: Jennifer Foster
review: The AT&T credit card is an excellent credit card to own. I think it it is a great card to use to pay off your At&T bill each month, since it does not have an annual fee, you earn a point for every $1 spent, and you get an additional 10,000 bonus points for the first $500 you spend. I feel that this is a good option to use, especially since the points will add up if the card is used to the purpose of paying off the bill each month. The good thing about the points is that they can be redeemable for $100 gift cards.

name: Joe Costello
review: I don't really see the benefit of the Radio Shack Store Card, especially in relation to similar store credit cards.  This card offers the typical 0% interest rate for the first 12 months and you get a discount off your first purchase.  Other than those, I don't see any other particular benefits of this card.  In fact, I think the interest rate after the introductory period is higher than other store credit cards.  The rewards program also leaves a lot to be desired.  It would be difficult for me to recommend this card.

name: Corey
review: The Brooks Brothers Credit Card seems to be pretty on par with other store cards. The $35 late fee is a little steep however, since most store cards I've seen only charge $20-25 for late payment. The interest rate between 14-21% seems pretty standard, and the cash advance rates are equally average. It should be noted that instead of the usual $10 minimum fee for cash advances, this card only charges $5 minimum per cash advance transaction, which might be nice for those who tend to need to get cash quickly from their cards. Finally, the reward system appears to be a little above average. Of all the aspects of this card, the rewards offered on purchases may be the one feature that makes it stand out from the others.

name: chris
review: The Sunoco Card can be a helpful tool for families with multiple cars that do a lot of driving.  You won't really start seeing good benefits until the 3rd time you fill up in a billing cycle; before then it's only 3 points per dollar spent, not 10.  With fuel economy on the rise, more and more people won't be able to get the maximum benefit for this type of card, as you find yourself timing your fillups to maximize one month at the expense of another.  Compare that to the .15/per gallon flat rate of the Exxon/Mobile card and you really can do better than this.  Now, if you drive a lot and there's some convenient Sunoco locations, this might be a helpful card.  But realistically, there's plenty of non gas related reward cards that give you better returns.  Just because you're buying gas doesn't mean you have to use a gas card.

name: grace mack
review: The Citi Diamond Preferred Card is my favorite credit card out of all the ones I currently own and use. I get 0% APR on every single purchase that I make in the first eighteen months that I use the card and after that they STILL offer some of the lowest interest rates around. The rates on the cash transfer option as well as the cash advance option are the lowest you will find. I have used this card for months now and it is always the first one that I reach for. The  access to presale tickets, preferred seating, VIP packages, as well as other rewards is my favorite thing about this card!

name: Jonathan Doebly
review: The Citi forward card is great. Its just as good as my USAA card but much less exclusive. The 0% interest rate was a nice surprise and even after that the 12% is still really low compared to most cards. The cash advance rate is high but thats just like every other card out there. The bonus points are also nice if that's your thing. The rules for the bonuses are clear cut and make a difference over time. The sign up bonus of 10,000 points was a great insinuative, it's like they handed me an extra hundred just for signing up. All together I was really pleases with the card and use it regularly just for the bonuses.

name: Jacqueline Cooley
review: I obtained the Best Buy card this past tax season, as I was trying to upgrade my computer and the one that I wanted was a bit out of my price range. The application process was quick and simple and the approval time was outstanding. I found out within minutes! There are multiple avenues for paying my bill, which makes it all the more convenient. If I'm in town, I can stop by the store. If it's late, I can pay online. I can even call the company and pay over the phone. The option for auto payment is great, but I haven't used this yet. I have, however, enjoyed the fact that I could change my due date. That has helped me arrange my bills the way I want them. Overall, I would recommend this card for anyone who is constantly buying electronics and would like a little help in the credit department.

name: jesse
review: The Home depot Store Card is an alright store card to use. I always am getting things for fix up the house. I am a new home owner and I am trying to fix up the house that I bought. This card is great because I don't always have the money to get the things I need for my projects. You can also get a lot of household items there that you would get from the grocery store like toilet paper and dish soap even if your low on funds. For me, it is one of my most frequently used cards because it's they got everything I need there. The interest rate is just average for a credit card and there isn't really many rewards at all for using the card. I would still recommend it to anyone who is a recent homeowner.

name: Ben Matthews
review: I honestly don't see any benefit to using the Sears Credit Card.  They do not offer any rewards on any purchases, either at Sears or elsewhere.  They promote having special financing options and monthly sales events, but without any specifics it's hard to know if they are worth holding out for to make your purchase at Sears.  You can also take advantage of similar deals at  Kmart, Sears.com, Kmart.com, Lands End, The Great Indoors.  I think you are better off using any type of reward based credit card.  Most give out at least 1% cash back on all purchases, which is a lot better than nothing.

name: jesse
review: The Citi Thank You Preferred Rewards Card is a pretty awesome card to. I like the idea of get points for things that I am going to purchase anyways. Once those points add up I can get myself free stuff or gas. My interest rate is only 13 percent and that is pretty reasonable for a credit card. The fact that there is no annual fee just makes this card that much better.  I don't transfer debts from one card to any other so the transfer fee does not apply to me.  Lastly, I love that the points don't ever expire. It would be crazy if you only had a limited amount of time to use the points before they disappeared.  All in all, this is a great card and I would really recommend this card to anyone.

name: Ben Matthews
review: The Shell Credit Card is not that great when you compare it to other rewards cards out there.  If you spend $500 in a single month they will give you 10 cents off per gallon on up to 100 gallons of gas on your next billing cycle.  If you were to spend exactly $500 on the card to get the benefit, you would get at most $10 off your gas.  That's the equivalent of 2% back.  And with every dollar you spend over $500, your savings goes down as the rewards are worth worse.  There is also a really high interest rate at 23.99% which means you ideally want to be paying it off every single month.

name: Ben Matthews
review: The Home Depot Store Card is really lacking any benefits that their competitors have.  All you can really do with a Home Depot card is 6 months of no interest financing if you pay off your bill within 6 months.  For comparison, the Lowes Credit Card offers the same deal or 5% back on every purchase.   Even the Menards card offers a 2% end of year rebate on all purchases.  I really wish they would have offered some sort of rewards for using their card, as I tend to pay off all my purchases immediately to avoid finance charges.  I would highly consider the Lowes card instead if you are making a big purchase and paying it off immediately.

name: Lori McKirahan Burton
review: I agree.  I applied for the card thinking I'd receive some incentive from HD to use it for purchases at their store, like Lowes gives, but nope.  I ended up cancelling my order with HD so I could order again using a different card.  I think HD's customer service department must be used to this type of explanation because they offered no incentive to keep the order placed.

name: Ben Matthews
review: I personally love the Best Buy Credit Card because I do a lot of shopping in their store.  The reward program works by giving you 2.5 points for every dollar spent.  It equals 5%, and for every $100 you spend in store you'll get a $5 gift card to use at Best Buy.  They also have special financing options if you are purchasing a lot of stuff there like a home theater setup, so that is something to keep in mind if you don't have the cash immediately to pay off your credit card.  The only thing about this card which is not great is that you must have excellent credit to get it, and if you apply for it and don't qualify they'll give you the lesser card that doesn't have as great of benefits.

name: Connor Fitzpatrick
review: I got the Best Buy credit card in an attempt to establish credit since I had none at the time. Store credit cards are a good way to do that. Since then, I have used over 20 times and have paid everything off on time. I haven't used it on anything huge like a washer or dryer since I still live at home, but I have used it on multiple video games, a desktop, and a laptop. The reward point system is GREAT. No one could complain about the extra 5 bucks for every 250 points, its just a great deal. There have been some discount offers, but I have never taken advantage of them. That is not saying the discount offers aren't good, its just I haven't really had a need for any of the items being offered at a discount. If you are a big electronics shopper or need to establish credit so you can qualify for a credit card, I would highly recommend the Best Buy credit card.

name: Ryan Saunders
review: I have had this particular card and account for a decade and have never once had a problem with the company.  When there is a dispute (and I have had a few in my time), the company is more than happy to work with, not against the customer in regards to negating the fraudulent charge as well as ensuring that protection is placed on the account. It is nice to know that there is still a credit card out there that I don't have to fear for using or losing for that matter and that everything will be just fine.

name: Ben Matthews
review: The Tire Kingdom Store Card is great if you need special financing with your tire purchase.  Tire purchases are not always planned, so most likely you don't have the money.  If that's a case they offer no interest 12 month financing with a $800 purchase, or 6 months of no financing if the price is over $200.  On top of that they'll give you a Visa gift card worth either $25 or $50 depending on how big your purchase is.  It's pretty great they they offer a reward like that instead of points which you get in cash back, because you'll probably never use this card anywhere else.

name: Stephanie Saathoff
review: This credit card was my first card and I have had it for six years. They are really good about checking to make sure I did that charge.  When someone did do a false charge, it was very easy to dispute it and get it resolved. Another plus to this credit card, their website allows you to pay your bill online and is very easy to use. They also let you set up automatic bill pay which is nice so you don't have to allows remember to submit your bills. This credit card is good for a first credit card too. The only downside is that the rewards aren't that great.

name: Ben Matthews
review: The Expedia Credit Card is below average for what is essentially an online store card.  You get 2% back on all Expedia.com purchases, and 1% back on everything else.  While this might seem good, a lot of major credit cards have online portals that will get you much bigger rewards for booking your travel.  For example, I got if you use your CapitalOne Venture card right now, you can get 3.25% back by booking with Expedia (1.25% with the card, 2% bonus by shopping through their portal).  This is not worth it when you consider how many places you'll have to use your card at only 1% cash back just to get your rewards out of the rewards program.

name: Ben Matthews
review: This Cit Secured Credit Card is different from normal credit cards.  If you've never used a secured card before, your credit limit is based on how big of a cash deposit you make on the card.  It's for people with bad or low credit that can't get a normal credit card.  While this card does come with an annual fee, I've noticed it's lower than other secured cards out there which is good.  This card will help you build up your credit which is good, but if you are not concerned about that you might want to get something like a Prepaid Card like American Express Serve which has very little fees associated with it.

name: Dan G
review: L.L. Beans Credit card is a basic card that offers pretty much the same cash back as any other card 1%. This card gets 3 stars because of that reason, small specific store cards are very nice if you shop at that specific store quite frequently, otherwise I would not suggest these. A positive thing about this is if you sign up for numerous cards for different stores and businesses, and only use the store specific cards there you will surely end up saving some money. A card I would recommend instead of this card is the PayPal Credit card, it allows you to gain tons of points and spend them on literally anything that accepts that service.  If you shop here frequently get yourself the card, otherwise I would suggest looking at some other options!

name: Ben Matthews
review: For a store card the Staples Store Card is pretty below average.  By buying things with the card you get 5% back, but you can get that without needing a credit card so I can't honestly factor it into this cards rewards program.  The only real benefit of this card are the perks you get in store.  If you own a business you might need the itemized receipts, or the dedicated line of credit for Staples only.  But I'm guessing that the average person does not need it.  Use a regular credit card and get at least 1% back, and use your Staples Rewards card in store and get the 5% back as well to maximize your spending.

name: Jessica Hoskins
review: We have had the Best Buy store credit card for a few years now. I originally signed up for it in order to make a big purchase in order to take advantage of the "no interest charged if paid off in full in six months" promotion. At that time it was a large television for our bedroom, and I found that paying in intstallments with the Best Buy Card was easy and with no interest it didn't cost us anything. Since then we have made several big purchases each year using the card, most recently a new washer and dryer, six months ago it was a dishwasher, etc. I would personally suggest using it to finance those big purchases. The advantages of the card include that it's very easy to apply for in the store and you can manage it online. The disadvantage is that the promotions run for a limited time and generally have dollar amounts associated with them, like you have to spend more than $300 at a time, etc. Also, if you miss a payment or are late they reserve the right to go back and charge you interest from day one. So keep that in mind, and if that is a problem for you I'd suggest looking elsewhere.

name: Andi Robb
review: As a big electrics fan I love best buy and the best buy store card. Although the APR is a little steep there is no annual fee to worry about like the Sony card I used to have and this balances it nicely. If you have the funds to pay the balance off right away they offer a standard reward point scheme of 1 point per dollar spent and if you buy a lot of electronics these points can really add up quickly. The added bonus of the $5 reward at each 250 points is sometimes a nice surprise too. There is a good introductory rate of only 11% and this is for 2 years so you can use the time building up your points without worrying about high interest rates taking up all the savings. Overall a really good card i highly recomend.

name: Ben Matthews
review: The Brooks Brothers Credit Card might seem like it's not as good as other store cards out there, but you need to consider all the other perks that come with it.  Typically store cards top out at 5% back, but this card gives you 4%.  What I love about it though is that they give you two $20 of coupons during the year just for having the card.  If you ever shop at Brooks Brothers, that alone is worth having this card in your wallet.  On top of that you get 15% off your first purchase, so save signing up for a day that you are going to go big.

name: Ben Matthews
review: The Radio Shack Store Card is not a good credit card to have.  The only benefit they have going for it is the no APR for 6-12 months depending on how big your purchase is.  So if you are that hard up for cash, this might be something to consider.  But if you do have the cash the rewards are horrible.  10% off your first purchase is nice, but you save relatively nothing after that.  You get 15% off store stocked batteries, but you'll be better buying batteries off of Amazon or CostCo to save more than 15% compared to Radio Shacks prices.

name: Ben Matthews
review: I find this card great for exclusively paying my AT&T bill for my iPhone.  I've yet to find a card that gives me 5% back on simply paying my AT&T bill.  I need a cell phone, so why not get some money off my bill each month?  There is a bonus of 10% off in the first year which is nice.  There are ways you can earn points for purchases other than AT&T stuff, but there are tons of other credit cards that give you more cash back.  Get this card if you have AT&T, otherwise give it a pass.  And if you do have the card, use something else like the Capital One VentureOne card for your every day purchases that gives you a nice 1.25% back instead of 1%.

name: Ben Matthews
review: I love the Best Buy Store Card because it gives me extra reward zone points that I can redeem for gift cards to Best Buy.  It's nice because it's a way to reward myself, instead of getting cash back on my bill I get to spend it on something for myself.  You basically get 5% back on all purchases made at Best Buy or on their website, and you can redeem points in $5 increments.  It's technically a little more than 5% back, because the gift cards they give you reduce the price of the item and you don't pay sales tax on it.  A nice unexpected bonus!

name: Priscilla Valle
review: The Home Depot Store Card is worth applying for in my opinion. The fact that you pay no interest if paid in full within 6 months is a fantastic feature for anybody that needs a quick pick me up or home repair but does not have the funds at that moment for any emergency. Another great feature is the no annual fee. You can feel free to have this card active at all times and not worry about getting charged fees if you choose not to use it. I actually own a Lowes card which has similar features as The Home Depot Store Card, for example no interest for 6 months as long as it is paid in full. I would prefer The Home Depot Store Card over the Lowes card due to my actual liking of Home Depot store and customer service over Lowes.

name: Constantina Hauser
review: Shell Credit Card does get quite use in our family.  We make a point to buy gasoline only from shell, my father used to buy gas from only shell too.  Kind of like a family tradition for us.   This card is nothing special and has a high interest rate, so I make a point of paying the balance in every cycle.  I have Citibank accounts and I feel comfortable using this card.  I have had this card for years and I have maximized my benefits using this card over the years.  Doesn’t everyone like bonus rewards?  Also their customer service is great too.

name: Constantina Hauser
review: I have had this card for so long and used only a handful of times mostly for purchases in auto department.  Sears does offer quality products and I enjoy shopping at the stores, therefore this card comes handy sometimes.  I am a Citibank customer so I have quite a bit of trust in this card.  But their rate is quite high so I would rather use it less than more.  One benefit of this card is that you can also it in Kmart stores which I seem to frequent quite often.  Overall, I am quite satisfied with this card and will keep it as long as sears stores are around.  I always wonder though, what happened to Roebuck ?

name: Allie Johnson
review: My Best Buy card is the only credit card that I have had that has never given me any problems. It was the first credit card I got when I turned 18. I decided to get a credit card to build my credit, and this one helped me do it. Made a few purchases with it and received a $50 gift card in the mail unexpectedly, nice! I called customer service regarding an online payment question, and they not only answered my question but they informed me that my APR has been lowered significantly. Bonus! I would recommend the card!

name: Kyle Storm
review: This is much better that the Sears credit card. It's got a prettier layout, and theres no anual fees unlike the sears card. I don't shop often at Best Buy since there isn't one in town, but I would definitely get this card if I went there more. The maximum late fee is very do-able, and I love that there is a long grace period.

name: Sidhu Ram
review: I have been an Expedia card user for a long time now. There is an important aspect that I would like to share as a part of the review which made me stick to using the card for a long time(about 6 yrs now). I used to make regular purchases with the card and I had no backlog/pending payment history. However, there came a time when I was short of money and I was defaulting for 6-7 months and the penalty started. When an executive contacted me regarding the overdue charges, I explained the situation to them and I immediately noticed the penalty being waived off! The explanation given was that I am a genuine customer for a long time and the company would like to waiver my penalty this one time considering my track record! Wonderful, isn't it?

name: robert mack
review: One of the best things about the Citi Simplicity Card is the fact that you pay NOTHING in interest on purchases made in the first 18 months. You will not find many cards that will be able to beat this. Add in the 0% interest rate on transfers and you have one of the best cards that are around right now. I tell all my friends about this card when they ask for my advice on credit cards. They have all loved it, as do I. I will continue using this card even after the intro period is over, as the interest rate is still one of the lowest around.

name: Alex Steven
review: The staples store card is a decent card. The reward for shopping at Staples is great; 5% back on all items bought. This is especially good for me since I recently went back to school and had to get a lot of pens and supplies, and typically restock on ink/paper/pens at Staples. I even bought an expensive fountain pen for a good price because of the rewards. The interest rate is pretty high, though, which isn't good. APR is also kind of high. If you see yourself at Staples a lot, this is an obvious choice. If not, there could be other cards for you.

name: Andi Robb
review: I think the Citi secured credit card is great! It is designed for people who have low or bad credit, with a low interest rate and can be used to rebuild credit. As its a secured credit card you need to place a deposit down on the card ($200) and then you can spend that(much like a prepaid debit card) however the cost for this is very reasonable as the annual fee is only $29 which is a lot lower than other cards like this. Having had a capital one card in the past I am much happier with this card, Lower APR, better customer service and fraud protection on top. Overall this card is great for rebuilding credit and good for getting back on your feet.

name: Alex Steven
review: The L.L.Bean Credit card is a  better card than I expected it to be. I like that you can get rewards for shopping wherever you go, it doesn't have to just be at L.L.Bean. Other than that, rewards aren't too good in my opinion. Since I don't do excessive shopping, I feel I don't get too much reward out of this card. Plus, I haven't been shopping at L.L.Bean as of recent, so I may get rid of this card, since shopping with them gives the biggest rewards. Interest rate can also be pretty high which isn't good for me. Overall, I think if you shop a lot, this is a good card for you.

name: Sheryl Papageorgio
review: The Tire Kingdom Store Card is a credit card you'll use for one purchase, and that's it.  They offer a $50 Visa Gift Card on a purchase of over $400, and a $25 gift card on purchases over $200.  Being a store card you can't use it anywhere else either.  That said, the main benefit would be if you cannot afford your purchase.  They offer interest free financing between 6 and 12 months if your purchase is above $800 or $200 respectively.  They do have minimum payments though, so it is also something to consider.  But chances are if you are shopping at Tire Kingdom you won't find a better interest free deal anywhere else.

name: Andi Robb
review: The best thing about this card is the fact that there is no fee each year. This is great if you only occasionally use the card rather than shopping there every week. The extras such as the cash back really work if you do all your office shopping at staples 5% on purchases can really add up. Although the APR is higher than some cards the payment options make it easy to pay the balance quickly while still gaining the benefits. Overall its worth having if you shop there a lot or tend to make 1 or 2 large purchases there per year. If you only occasionally shop there for little things and hold a balance on your cards there are other cards that will serve you better.

name: ursula kafka
review: The Sears Credit Card is just your basic average no frills store credit card. It's a good choice if you shop at Sears or Kmart a lot because they do have special offers and sales events for cardholders, but otherwise take a pass on this one. There's no annual fee but there's also no rewards or guaranteed discounts. The interest rate is rather high and not variable, so I would really only get this card for smaller purchases that you can pay off before the end of the billing cycle or just to take part in the sales that are only available to cardholders.

name: ursula kafka
review: The Home Depot Store Card is pretty much a must have for homeowners who don't have a general rewards card. The interest rate peaks at a pretty high point but it IS variable, unlike the Lowe's card. It's also available if you have less than perfect credit. The 0% interest if paid in full by six months really makes this card great for people just starting out in a new home. If you have a general rewards card available to you, that is probably a better choice as, unlike most store cards, you don't earn cash back with the Home Depot card.

name: Hana
review: The Best Buy card is a really good card. I like that there is no annual fee, because it gives me one less thing to worry about. I already have to worry about bills from other cards. Another thing I enjoy is that the card gives me reward points. I get to earn the points and when I get enough I can get a $5 certificate from just spending money on something I would have purchased in the first place. I also like to buy similar items from Home Depot, but compared to Best Buy's credit card, the Home Depot card doesn't have a rewards program. I prefer the Best Buy card for the rewards aspect, also their apr is slightly lower which is another plus. The only negative is the high late fee of $35, but since I always pay on time I do not face that problem.

name: Ed Lukshides Jr.
review: Best Buy always has the great financing offers, especially when you are making large purchases.  The no interest financing options at the different tiered levels, based on your purchase price, fit into any budget and who doesn't like no interest!  I've purchased everything from a nook, to an iPad, a Macbook and multiple digital cameras on my store card and I'm always able to get a financing plan that allows me to pay the same as cash for as little as 6 months and up to 18 months.  I've had the card since 2002 and it's probably the favorite card in my wallet.  I was approved for a very reasonable amount and I've only had to request an increase to my maximum once, maybe I use the card to much sometimes:)  The bottom line if you like electronics like I do you can't go wrong with this card!

name: Francine Calandra
review: I really like the Citi® Diamond Preferred® Card because it has a  % interest rate for the first year, with only a max late fee of $35.00. I have had other credit cards such as American Express charge me as much as 45.00 in late fees. I also like the fact that there is a 0 % balance Intro APR on Balance Transfers and Purchases for 18 months because it allows me to transfer high interest charges like from my Aamco card which is at a high interest rate of 29%. With this card it gives me the time time to buy down that high interest loan charge into one low rate for 18 months. I also like the idea that the carrier is nor responsible if the card is stolen and then used by the person who stole the card. I had my wallet stolen a few months back and my discover card did not waive any charges that were brought onto the card by the thief.  Finally I love the fact that there is no annual fee because that frees up more of my money to spend on things I need or want unlike the Southwest credit card that demands their customer to pay an annual service fee.  to add I also like that there is a 23 grace period because with the Bank of America credit card that do not allow you any grace period at least with Citi® Diamond Preferred® Card if i am a little late there is a little time to pay. Makes me feel like this credit card actually knows that real people own this card, that we are not robots who always remember to pay on time.

name: Miz Michele'
review: I used to be one of those people who applied for, and had, just about every kind of credit card you could think of, until I realized that was not a smart thing to do.  I whittled down my pile and am so glad I kept the Staples card.The biggest benefit is the 5% cash back on all of your purchases, whether it is online at your local Staples. I find I use it more than some of the other office supply charge cards I kept because they do have some great finds in the store, particularly their notebook system that has removable pages.The downside is their APR rate. It's very high so to get the most out of the 5% cash back is to simply pay your bill in full so you realize the full benefit.  If you do that, it's a great card to have.

name: abigail lee
review: The Citi forward card is a great credit card for people who go out a lot. I have had this credit card for about 9 months and I mainly use it for dining. I get 5 points for every $1 that I spend. I just have to remind that I for other stores, I only get 1 point. After a couple of months, I am able to redeem my points for a gift card. I usually redeem it for a Macy's gift card. Overall, a good credit card for restaurants. Other than that, you can get better benefits with other credit cards.

name: Judy Walters
review: The Sunoco Credit Card sounds like a good idea if you use mostly Sunoco gas. The rewards would add up quickly, but I don't like that it doesn't tell you what you can use the points for. I like that there is no annual fee so if you don't actually use it, then you don't have to pay the fee just to have it. I'm also a little concerned about the base APR being 16.99% but it does not indicate how high it could go especially since it is a variable rate card. In my experience, the credit card companies love to offer variable rate cards so they can raise your rate if you make a late payment.

name: Kyle Rindfleisch
review: It doesn't seem like there's enough incentive to buy this Radio Shack Store Card. The 10% discount is nice, but it only applies to the first purchase, whereas something like the Target credit card gives 5% off on every purchase. The discount on the batteries is a nice idea too, but I buy batteries less and less every year and I can only think of, like, three things I use batteries for anymore. I also don't usually go to Radioshack. All of the things I would normally buy there are available at larger stores where I can also buy groceries and dvds and clothes and stuff like that, therefore a Radioshack store card would be almost worthless to me and would certainly not be convenient.

name: Adelama Adana
review: I have been using this card since I first needed to get a credit card in 2003, and have been pretty happy with it. I haven’t used its rewards program at all, but I prefer just having a simple set-up with no annual fee. I have found support from their website and over the phone to be quite good, and have a really easy time getting problems resolved quickly. On a couple of occasions where I had charges that I disputed, I was able to get the charges reversed and settled within 24 hours. On another occasion, when I was unable to make a payment because I had needed to evacuate due to a fire, they reversed my late payment fee when I called – there was no need to submit proof. The only real negative I’ve run into is that their payments are accepted according to Eastern time, and I live in Pacific time, so I’ve accidentally had a late payment when I tried to pay my bill after 9 pm on the due date. I wish that had been made a bit clearer on their bills and website.

name: Alex Steven
review: I like that this card (Brooks Brothers credit card) rewards you for shopping there. I’ve shopped at Brooks Brothers before, but I’m not sure if I shop there enough for me to justify having this card. If you don’t buy things at Brooks Brothers frequently, I would say not to buy this card. I like the low foreign transaction fee, but the rates seem pretty average. For regular people, this is a 3/5. For Brooks Brothers customers, I'd give this card a 4/5. Also, I liked that you get extra rewards on your birthday and anniversary. That's something I don't see too often, so it was pretty neat for a card to do that.

name: Bob Steve
review: The ATT Universal Business Rewards card offers 5% back on AT&T services, 3% back on gas, office supplies, and professional services, and 1% back elsewhere. While these are great benefits, you're most likely better off with Chase Ink Business. The Chase card offers 3% back on gas, restaurants, office supplies, and home improvement stores. Also, the ATT card maxes out at 100,000 points a year while the Chase Ink has no rewards limit. On top of that, the Chase card also offers a much lower minimum APR.

name: Kathryn
review: I got this card back in 2007 when I wanted to buy a digital camera. I didn't have the best credit at the time, but they approved me on the spot for $300. I was able to get the camera that I wanted, including the accessories. I paid the minimum payment on the card for a while, which of course led to a higher APR, but I was college at the time and wasn’t thinking about it much. When I finally had the money to completely pay off the card, the online system was really easy to use. I decided to cancel the card soon after to avoid buying more electronics that I didn’t need, but it was good for what I needed.

name: Sheryl Papageorgio
review: The Expedia Credit Card is pretty average.  You would expect the rewards for shopping a Expedia to be much better, but you might get more cash back using a Chase Sapphire card during the quarter that they offer travel bonuses.  The Expedia Credit Card only gives you 2% back on purchases at Expedia, and 1% back everywhere else.  I would expect at least 5% back with a card geared towards using Expedia.  Especially because my Capital One Venture card gives me more than 2% back when using their online portal with Expedia.  Definitely not worth it, and check out your current credit cards online portals to see if you have any big Expedia bonuses as well.

name: Sheryl Papageorgio
review: If you plan on making a big purchase at Staples, the Staples Store Card is a no brainer.  It's reward system is simple, you get 5% back on all purchases at Staples every single day.  This is great if you have a business which frequently visits staples, or even if you plan on making some big purchases like a computer, office furniture, or anything really.  Typically store cards top out around 5%, and Staples is no different.  Office supply is not a common category to get 5% back on with other credit cards, so the Staples Store Card is worth looking in to for sure.

name: Paul Hunter
review: I like Expedia Credit Card because not only does it have no preset spending limit, it also offers a lot of rewards. One of the things that really caught my eye was the travel and emergency assistance. To have that available all the time is an amazing asset and would really put people at ease. I also liked the idea of having auto rental insurance available. Rental companies can be quite picky about the vehicle when you rent it and its good to know somebody will have your back. This card has amazing rewards, a fair rate, and no preset spending limit. I don't think I could ask for more.

name: Sheryl Papageorgio
review: The Citi Secured Credit Card is a secured credit card for those that have bad credit.  If you are not familiar with how secured credit cards work, you place a deposit on the card that basically is the size of your credit limit.  Secured cards usually come with annual fees, and this cards fees are reasonable at only $29 a year.  On top of that, you do get MasterCard's standard fraud protection as well, which some secured cards do not offer.    The main benefit of this card over other secured cards is that you do earn interest on your deposit.

name: Sheryl Papageorgio
review: The L.L. Bean Credit card is similar to most store cards out there.  They give you a standard 1% back on all your purchases made anywhere you shop, but the real bonus come from shopping in the store.  You can get 3% back on all purchases made at LL bean with this card, plus special perks such as coupons and access to exclusive sales only eligible for card members.  This card is worth it if you do a lot of shopping at L.L. Bean, but that would be the only place I'd recommend using the card.  In comparison, L.L. Bean offers decent rewards, but other store cards offer typically around 5% like the Target RED card.

name: Michael Concialdi
review: I have had this credit card since my college days. That was 10 years ago and I am happy to say I have been very pleased with this credit card. Citi Bank was the only company that gave me a chance as a young adult to build up my credit. Over the years I have received frequent credit line increases, low APR’s, and no annual fees. They also have great balance transfer offers which have helped me immensely during tough economic times. There cash back program caps you at $300 but that’s still a fair amount of money to receive just for using your credit card. I recommend this card to all college students who are looking to get a jump start on building a solid credit history.

name: Sheryl Papageorgio
review: The City Forward card has some nice benefits if you spend your money in fun entertainment categories such as books, music and movies.  Those categories earn 5% back, as opposed to 1% back on everyday purchases at other stores.  The cool thing about the City Forward card though is that they have a very nice sign up bonus.  By spending $650 in the first three months they will give you $100 in gift cards!  Keep in mind that you will also need to sign up for paperless statements or else you won't get the gift card bonus.  Overall it's a good credit card to have in your wallet for spending on the fun things in life.

name: chris
review: The Citi Diamond Preferred Card is a solid card, but with nothing that makes it stand out from the pack.  You need top level credit to even get the card, which makes it somewhat surprising there aren't bigger advantages to using it.  The 18 month intro rate of 0% APR is the only thing that stands out as better than a typical credit card such as the Capital One Platinum Prestige card that I currently use, which has nearly identical features but isn't as difficult to get.  If you qualify for it, it's a helpful card, but if you qualify for this you should be able to find a card that gives comparable interest rates with much better perks or rewards.  At best this gives you an 11.99% rate after the introductory period which is nice but certainly not the best you could do.

name: Sheryl Papageorgio
review: The Sunco Credit Card promises as much as 10% back on your gas purchases, but you really have to read the detailed to figure out how to get it.  The rewards are based on how many purchases you make in your cards billing period.  You get 3% back on your first and second fill ups, and then 10% back on every fill up after that.  If you get your gas exclusively as Sunco this could be the card for you, as even the 3% back on the initial fill ups is better than most reward credit cards.  Just keep in mind that you won't see the 10% back until the third use each month.  On the plus side though, there are no annual fees!  I would recommend this for anybody that frequently uses Sunco and is looking to get some cash back on their fuel.  But this is not a card to use for your every day purchases.

name: John S Dunning
review: This card is great. I needed a new washer and dryer for my home, because mine had broke. So I applied online for this card. It was simple to apply. I was approved within a minute and had a $3000.00 credit limit. I went and bought my new washer and dryer and used the card. The payments were within a good range and I love how simple it is to make the payments online. Anytime I need something new for my home, shop at Best Buy and use this card. I also like how every so often they will run specials on products that you can charge to your card and get a lower APR.

name: Sheryl Papageorgio
review: The Best Buy Store Card has been a pretty great way to rack up reward points over the years that I've had it.
