Every purchase you make online or in store gives you the equivalent of 5% back in Reward Zone Points that can be used towards cashing out for gift certificates.  The nice thing is that you can combine this offer with other reward zone promotions, maxing out the amount of points you can earn.  It's the best way to shop at Best Buy to maximize your cash back while getting stuff you love.  I just wish the default amount of points you get on every day purchases at other stores was just as good.

name: Gina Honrath
review: This is a pretty good credit card for Brooks Brothers fans. It reminds me a lot of my American Eagle credit card. One of the best parts about this card is your first purchase you get an automatic 15% off. I also love the fact that you earn 4 points for every one dollar spent in the store. This is awesome because a lot of stores will only do 1 point per dollar. Another awesome thing about this card is that you get free shipping on all of your orders, which I have never have offered with any of my other cards. I also love that they send you a $20 card for 2,000 points, anniversary, and birthday! My victorias secret card does the same thing and I love it. This card is great for Brooks Brothers shoppers, but if you are not a fan of the clothing line I would consider getting another card somewhere else.

name: Sheryl Papageorgio
review: I would not advise getting the Radio Shack Store Card.   While you get a discount of 10% off your first purchase, that is the only good reward offer this card has.  While they do offer no interest for 6 or 12 months depending on the purchase price, the APR beyond that is higher than most cards out there.  When you factor in they don't have a rewards program for every day purchases even at their own store, I cannot recommend this card.  If you must shop at Radio Shack, use another rewards credit card that will give you at least some sort of cash back on your purchase.

name: Sheryl Papageorgio
review: The only thing the AT&T Credit card is really good for is paying for your cell phone bill.   It has a first year bonus of 10% cash back, and then 5% bonus after that.  It's pretty good for a credit card reward system, as you will very rarely find another card that offers that big of a cash back on AT&T.  That said, the rest of the rewards are pretty average at what amounts to 1% back on every day purchases.  Good if you have AT&T, but is it worth having an extra card in your wallet to save an extra 3-4%?

name: aadff bdaf
review: The Best Buy Credit Card is pretty decent for a store credit card. The low conversion threshold for rewards points makes it easy to actually cash out rewards, instead of saving up massive amounts of points to finally receive one gift certificate, like at some other stores. The rewards for spending at Best Buy stores are also pretty great, since you can get 5% back in rewards, which is pretty rare for most store credit cards. The intro APR is pretty nice, and can help in a pinch during the holiday season. The rate for balance transfer is a touch higher than other cards, but otherwise this card is nice for frequent shoppers at Best Buy.

name: chris
review: Unfortunately, I don't see myself getting a lot of use out of a Sears Credit Card.  It's similar to other department store cards such as the Macy's Credit Card I already have.  The interest rate is well below average, so it's not great to use for large purchases you need time to pay off fully.  For this Sears card, you don't even get a discount off your first purchase like you do for most department store cards.  Thankfully, there's no annual fee either, so your best bet is to get this card for the sales events, and then use another card to make the actual purchases.

name: aadff bdaf
review: The Shell Credit Card is not really anything too special. The interest rate is kind of steep on this, and there's no variation on it, which kind of sucks. One good thing is that you can check your card's statements and other information online, making it a lot easier to track spending or just do a quick check on your last purchases. The rewards are kind of hard to hit if you have a car with good mileage, or just don't use that much gas. Also, the discount per gallon of gas will likely be mitigated by the increase in price for using credit, making the rewards only alright.

name: aadff bdaf
review: The Home Depot Store Card is pretty snazzy. Even though the interest rate is pretty high, their offer for 0% interest if paid in full by six months makes this a very attractive card for those that need to shop here a lot. It also helps that they have an online service for their store card, making it easier to manage finances, especially when these credit cards are only available for use at the store it's offered at. Also, the range of APR's makes this better than some other cards, like the Lowe's card which only offers 24.99% no matter what. This may be useful if you frequent Home Depot.

name: brian
review: The Citi Secured MasterCard Credit Card is an option for those trying to build credit or those that need to restore their credit after hard times. Unfortunately for someone that might need this card, the terms are not very good. To get the card you need to put up 200 dollars of your own money. Also there is an annual fee. I have few other cards that do not have annual fees and do not charge me for having the card. Also 18.24% seems pretty high to me for a credit card especially one with an annual fee. The only card I use with an annual fee gives me upgrades for flights and adds to my frequent flyer miles. I do not suggest this credit card for most people although it is probably a good fit for some.

name: ursula kafka
review: The LL Bean store credit card is a lot different than other store cards out there. First, you get rewards no matter where you shop. The 1% on all purchases at stores other than LL Bean could really add up over time. Second, they have a decent variable interest rate - unlike most store cards where it's nearly 30%. They also have exclusive sales in-store for cardholders, so if you are a frequent shopper at LL Bean this card provides a lot of benefits. You also get free shipping and return shipping, which will save you a ton of money over time.

name: ursula kafka
review: This would be a great card for just about anyone who ever shops at Staples. 5% back on all purchases, so even if you're an infrequent customer you'll get something out of it. If you're thinking of making a big purchase, this is like an automatic discount. The Staples Store Card is like a lot of store cards in that they'll give it to almost anybody and the interest rates are astronomical. Just pay off your balance before it accrues interest and you're getting a bargain. I think this would be a good card for someone who needs to build up their credit, as well.

name: aadff bdaf
review: I really, really like the initial bonus offer on the Expedia Credit Card! $50 for just any purchase is pretty great. Other than that, though, the rewards program for this card just seems kind of lackluster compared to the other great cards out there. Also, theirs is a points-based program, usually meaning that their points probably aren't a 1:1 ratio for points to cents. I'd much rather prefer straight cashback. Plus, there are a lot of great travel credit cards out there from other companies that offer much more in the way of rewards. If your credit is great, then it may be worthwhile to get a free $50 from their sign-up offer at the very least.

name: Julie Johnson
review: I picked up my Tire Kingdom Store Card while looking for a new set of tires, simply so I could take advantage of the $50 Visa Prepaid Card that they offer, and I have found myself using it more and more. I have found myself using the card very frequently and often times preferring it over my Capital One Platinum Card, simply because I have had nothing but great experiences using the Tire Kingdom Store Card, whether I am buying new tires for my ATV or taking my car in for an oil change, every transaction has been quick and easy.

name: Eric
review: This Citi ThankYou card is perfect if you want to open a new card and not have to worry about the initial financing fees that most rewards cards stick you with. The 15 months introductory offer of 0% interest is fantastic.  You can easily make purchases and if you run a little tight on money one month you don't have to worry about getting dinged with interest charges if you wait a month to pay it off.  This is one of the greatest perks of this card, because if you have a balance transfer or new purchases to make you can make them on this card and pay no interest for 15 months.  If you go out to eat frequently this card will slowly pay for itself.  Especially since the points don't expire on this card.  If you need to make a balance transfer and need a little time to pay it off this card will give you the breathing room you need.  I find it to be a fantastic card.

name: Kenneth Woolley
review: The main reason I got the Citi Simplicity Mastercard was for the 0% APR for 18 months. This is a great feature and a huge help in not getting out of hand with money. There are also no late fees which adds even more to the value of the card. It seems that this is a foolproof card and the features seem almost too good to be true from a credit card company. Another great feature that there are no annual fees. Basically get this card if you can because the features for the card pretty much are the best deal around. It's a dream come true as far as credit cards is concerned.

name: Sandy Hogue
review: The Citi Forward is a great card, especially if you are just starting out. I originally got mine as a student to cover school expenses, but was happy to continue using it beyond graduation. The points rewards are decent, but they definitely get the most mileage on Amazon.com. I especially like that I can pay for Amazon orders directly with my points.My only complaint would be that the points to cash-back ratio isn’t as good as the points to Amazon purchases ratio. It would also be nice to have more cash-back and points options on regular purchases such as gas and groceries. Nonetheless, I’m very happy with Citi Forward.

name: Dallas Hawkins
review: I believe the Goodyear Store Card is just an okay card. I would only suggest it if you already go to Goodyear exclusively for car maintenance and repair, otherwise it is probably not for you. The APR is just under 29%, which is very high for even a store card, so only open this account if you know you can pay off your balance monthly. It also has no annual fee, which is a plus, but this is becoming more and more standard with store cards. In the end, I would not suggest this card to anyone unless you are a repeat customer of Goodyear and can take advantage of the promotions and discounts they offer, and only use it sparingly and pay it off regularly since the interest rate is very high.

name: aadff bdaf
review: The ExxonMobil Credit Card doesn't seem like anything worth writing home about. Sure, the 15 cent rebate per gallon seems pretty nice, but gas stations typically charge extra for credit card charges anyways. This just seems to cancel out the extra charge of using a credit card. Plus, there's no intro 0% APR that tons of other credit card providers are offering nowadays. There needs to be some other incentive to this card, otherwise it would be better to just get other credit cards that offer 3% on gas, like the BankAmericard Cash Rewards card. I would not recommend this card unless it's the only gas cashback card that you can get, or you really like ExxonMobil.

name: Paula Flaquer
review: We've had this card for quite a few years now, but it's mostly because we don't like to cancel credit cards unless we absolutely have to more than because it is so good. Basically, we've built up a nice big limit on it so it serves for booking large expenses like cruises, and the interest rate is not bad. As far as perks however, this card is pretty much the worst I've seen. They have the Citi Easy Deals which is pretty much a joke. In order to get any discounts, you mostly have to purchase something first and put up some of your own money. It comes off as another way for them to make money more than a way for me to get rewarded for my loyalty. Every other card I've had you can at least redeem points for cash. So I guess that's my main problem with it. Customer service isn't the best either, I've called once to ask questions about upgrading to  a better card and they were audibly sounding annoyed and never mailed me the brochure I asked for. So that's that, if it wasn't because of credit repercussions we would've probably cancelled it by now.

name: Tiffany McLean
review: The Citi Simplicity Card looks like it has many great features. The first thing I noticed was that there is no annual fee. That's great for a credit card because there are many out there like the Southwest Credit Card that requires an annual fee of at least $69. No fee means you keep more money in your pocket. The 0% APR for 18 months is also a great thing. A lot of the times with credit cards it's the interest that really gets you in the end. I can't believe there are no late fees! It's hard to find a card anywhere that doesn't have late fees but that is what sells me on this card. It looks like a great deal.

name: Ileddy Torres
review: The Shell Gas card is not what it seems. It obviously has nothing to do with gas, so I feel like I personally wouldn't be able to get much use out of it as I would a regular gas card. However, for the rewards they offer I think it is pretty awesome. I would enjoy getting some extra perks when I do travel. Their cashback/reward options seem great, although not as good as I have seen. I also prefer my Capital One credit card rewards which I can use for anything, with a lower apr and no annual fees.

name: Mika Aville
review: I have a Best Buy store card that has gotten me out of a few jams in the past.  The APR is great and the reasonable interest has let me pay off more than a few share of items that I have gotten with it.  I owe this card my television, Xbox, and my new surround system that I am going to get for my theatre room.  Best Buy is a great company in general to get things from as they were flexible with my payments as long as I paid in full.  I highly recommend this in store card to anyone looking to get one.

name: Chris Bova
review: I got this card in college when I needed a laptop but was short on cash. The intro APR was fairly low and lasted for a long time. I had plenty of time to pay off the computer before the much higher regular APR kicked in. I would definitely recommend the card if you have a large electronics purchase to make and know you can pay it off within the intro APR period. Getting approved in the store took a little bit of time but was relatively painless.

name: Donald Pinckney
review: This credit card is about the only reason that I continue to shop at best buy for big ticket items. With Frys, Micro Center, and Amazon being cheaper and having generally a better selection of tech items the financing that best buy offers continues to pull me back in. Also reward zone points have been scaled back considerably so I honestly haven't purchased anything there in a while due to amazon offering 2 day delivery.  Best Buy also has offered great financing offers like 3 years no interest on the last television I purchased. They simply need to up their side offers to get me back in store buying again.

name: James
review: I really like this credit card a lot, it is one of my favorite.  The reason I say this is because I use this video card to buy video games for my gaming consoles.  When the video games first come out, I usually pay it first using credit card because then I can pay back later.  When I first tried to get the credit card, I was approved very quickly and that made happy.  Once I find the product that I want to buy, I usually pay it with credit card because I can wait a month to pay for the product that I purchased.  Pay bill online is very easy and simple and the process takes only few minutes.

name: aadff bdaf
review: I just recently received this Citi Dividend Card for College Students about three weeks ago. So far, it is pretty nice. The only thing is that I wish I would have signed up for the non-student one. That way, I could have gotten the $100 dollar bonus for spending $500 in the first three months. However, the rewards for this card are phenomenal. While I do not use any of Q3's bonus offers, I am certain that the fourth quarter of this year will have some amazing bonus cashback opportunities. I also enjoy the fact that Citibank has the greatest online security of any bank, making me feel safe whenever I check my accounts online. All in all, this is a nice card, especially given the opening APR and cashback, and easy approval. Definitely recommend for college students looking to build credit.

name: Korra
review: Citibank is the first and only bank I've been a part off.  At first I had some issues and kind of hated this bank, but it all worked out.  Basically, for some reason, my debit card would be frozen, and it seemed to take FOREVER to get a hold of a representative that  could unfreeze it.  The process was extremely frustrating, and I was not able to use my card AT ALL for about two days, but after I called about 5 times in a row,  the Citibank workers were able to fix my card.  After that it was smooth sailing with the exception of being charged $3.00 at ATMs that didn't pertain to Publix of Citibank's branch itself.  The first month of being a member I regretted choosing this bank, but now, years later, I can honestly say that this bank is WONDERFUL.  Their customer service has seemed to improve drastically and I now definitely appreciate free withdrawal from Publix ATMs.  After using this bank for such a long time, I would gladly recommend it to anyone.

name: Robyn Seneca
review: The main issue I see with this card is the insane interest rate!  I understand that most cards have high interest rates, especially these days, but I wouldn't feel comfortable using this beyond gas purchases because of the fact that they do offer incentives.  I could see this card being very beneficial if you spend a lot of time on the road because Shell stations are everywhere.  All of the other information seems fairly typical of cards; the cash advance fee, the maximum late penalty and grace period, etc.  I don't see it being any better or worse than most cards in that respect.

name: eva mckinnon
review: I love this card! The reason i signed up for this card is I was in the store one day shopping for a new surround sound system and I seen one that i absolutely loved but couldn't afford at the moment, I was approved almost instantly and was able too get what i really wanted in the store.  I love the fact that they give you a good amount of time with little interest rate, too give you a chance to pay off the items before the rates get high. I would recommend this card to any of my friends of family members.

name: Skab Duded
review: The Home Depot Credit Card has worked great for us.  We signed up for one when our washing machine broke down unexpectedly and we needed a new one.  I thought the APR for the card appeared high, but looking at other store cards, I guess it's not.  Home Depot regularly sends offers for no interest for a given number of months on a purchase over a certain amount.  These are very useful for unforeseen major appliance failures.  I also really like the fact that I can access the credit card balance online through their website.  Even more useful, the balance can be accessed through mint.com, which we use for budgeting purposes.  The paper statements that they send in the mail are easy to read and easy to spot in the mail.  This makes for easy bill payment.  I'm very happy with this card and would definitely suggest others check it out, too.

name: Tiffany McLean
review: The big plus on this Sears Credit Card is it allows you to take part in different discounts and sales that the store has each month. Other than that is just seems like another credit card. Places like Macy's and Kohl's do the same things with there cards. The discounts are only helpful if you have something you need from this particular store. It would be great if they would offer rewards and then this card would have a leg up on other similar cards. The APR isn't too much higher than I've seen with other cards so no big deal there.

name: Tiffany McLean
review: We've had Home Depot Store Cards in our family before and they have always been very beneficial. If your house is like ours it is always in need of some fixing up and the Home Depot Card is a great way to make sure you can do that without going way over on your monthly budget. There aren't any incentives like bonuses or anything like that but the APR isn't too high, though it's higher than the Lowe's Business card. The no interest if paid within 6 month option is a great deal. It does require a certain dollar amount to receive that deal but if you're going to make a big purchase it's very helpful.

name: Tonio Stewart
review: This card is pretty decent . The APR is pretty standard compared other cards.  If you're a male and want the finest in quality suits, shirts, and formal shoes, then Brooks Brothers is at the top of the list for me. The reward points are great if you're a frequent shopper and in a few trips, it could really pay off. You also get 15% off your first purchase with the card. Make sure you take full advantage of it. I'm a current cardholder and unless the company folds, I'll be a cardholder for the foreseeable future. It's a great investment for the future.

name: Andi Robb
review: I think the radio shack store card is fair, as with all store cards it is only useful if you use the store on a regular basis and as other reviewers have said if you prefer online shopping than this card wont be for you. Having said this with no fee there is no reason not to have this card in your pocket and use it when needed. The interest rate is quite high for a store card unlike old navy and others but this is countered by the breaks you get for high value purchases (6 months interest free for purchases over $150 etc.) and the discount on batteries (15%) is great in the run up to xmas if you have kids and are buying lots of battery using toys. Overall it wont cost you anything to have it and it may come in handy for those big purchases.

name: Michael Staino
review: The AT&T credit seems like an average credit card.  For those who have AT&T, it may benefit them to use this card.  With 10% cash back on all AT&T products, it is a sensible decision to earn money back on products you regularly purchase.  However, if you do not have AT&T, nothing special sticks out to begin using their card.  I'm not a big fan of "reward points." I'd rather see cash value than having to wonder what I'm going to spend my points on.  Reward points always seem good in theory, but somehow I always end up spending them on something I don't really want.  So yeah, if you have AT&T great, but if you're like me and don't, I'd continue to look around.

name: Russell Slocum
review: Overall, the Goodyear Store Credit Card  is not a very good card. Even among store cards the interest rate is 3-6% over most. But fear not, it does not an annual fee nor do you have to pay exactly on time every month. And I have to admit, the lack of a severe penalty APR is quite enticing.Clearly this is not a card for the consumer who has 1-2 credit cards that that you pay in full every month. But if you do not have credit or are trying to restore previously damaged credit, then this is the card for you. There are far worse cards out there to build credit on, plus the occasional discount on automotive stuff is quite nice.

name: Benjy Saloman
review: I kind of like what I'm reading about the Citi Simplicity credit card. There is no max APR penalty or late fee and you get 0% APR for the first 18 months of being a card member. On my Visa G rewards, the intro rate was 1.99% for the first 6 months. The regular rate on this card is 12.99-21.99% depending on your credit score. Not so bad if you can keep on the low end. On my Provident and G rewards cards, I sit roughly between 14-15 %. This card is intriguing to me. There are no rewards, however- at least none that are listed. This may be a difficult card to obtain if you don't already have an excellent credit score, but if you do, I think having a card like this could be quite nice. I think I'm going to investigate it further.

name: Alex Eagle
review: I like the fact that the Shell Gas Card does not put a cap on the amount that you are able to earn from your rewards. As a person that drives a lot for work it makes it a great card to have! The $1,000 emergency cash is an awesome perk to have. It takes the stress off of my mind that I will ever be in an emergency situation that I will not have assistance to get out of. The rate is OK/middle of the road but the advance perk more than makes up for it. This is the card to have for anybody that has a big commute to work or regularly drives a lot of miles.

name: Hana
review: This card comes in pretty handy whenever I need to buy appliances. I got the card when I first bought a new washing machine a year ago. The customer service representative explained the benefits and it seemed just right. I was able to buy my washing machine and could pay it off in increments. The good thing about this card is that there is no interest if paid in full within 6 months of purchasing the item. This gives me a lot of time to enjoy the purchase without worrying about the money issue. The next time I was able to purchase a new refrigerator and used the card in the same way as before. The only negative thing is that the  APR is a little high, but as long as you pay everything off in time, there is no worry. There have never been any problems with my purchases and would highly recommend the Home Depot Store card to others that want to save money.

name: Lenaye Harris
review: The AT&T Card is a basic 1% cash back credit card. The initial bonus offer of $100 is on par with other credit card offers, such as Chase Freedom and the American Express Blue Cash Everyday cards. However, the only unique benefit to the AT&T card is 10% on AT&T products for the first year, 5% thereafter. If AT&T were my mobile provider, this would be somewhat beneficial, but compared to other cards, this seems very limited. American Express offers 3% back on groceries; Chase Freedom offers 5% back on quarterly categories. This card could be appealing to a small business or an individual with a very high phone or internet bill through AT&T, but average users will probably prefer a card with more versatile rewards.

name: Benjy Saloman
review: The Brooks Brothers credit card looks alright if you are a fan of the clothing line. The variable APR, 14.24-21.24% is not bad in comparison to other retailers. Most, Belks, JC Penny etc., run about 25% as their base rate.  Not so bad on this card. I think if you frequent the store, it may just be worth having this card. The initial 15% off bonus for signing up is a nice perk. The max earn, 4, for rewards points is also higher than many of the cards I have seen. Belk and JC Penny offer only 1 point max, for example.  It also looks like you get a 20 dollar off card on your birthday and Anniversary of signing up. That is also not a bad deal. I have to admit, and I am a pretty hard sell, this looks like a decent card. I may have to take a look again at Brooks Brothers and see if there is enough I would like to buy to merit this card.

name: Lisa Baer
review: I agree with what a lot of the other reviewers are saying about the Radio Shack Store Card. If you love Radio Shack and go there a lot for your needs, then yes!- this is the card for you, most likely. But if you're a lover of all things Amazon, ebay, and Wal-Mart...then maybe you should look elsewhere. The APR is pretty high so I hope you don't carry a balance. Honestly, it seems a lot like the Target Credit card with the initial 10% off and then the periodic rewards. I had the Target credit card for a bit, but I just didn't think the rewards were worth it, but I hope it's not the case with this card!

name: Shane Vicknair
review: I got a Best Buy credit card because I was installing a new home theatre system in my home, and thought that by using the card, I could extend on what I was able to buy. I was approved almost immediately, all they needed was my driver's license and a signature. I got approved for a bit more than I was expecting, so along with the TV and speaker system, I also got me a new fridge! They were offering three years no interest, so I've got a bit to pay off yet, but am excited that I'll be able to take my time on paying it off fully.

name: Ariana Morris
review: I only apply for credit cards when they have great introductory offers, and no annual fees or application fees. The Citi Thank You people sent me an offer where if I spent $1000 in the first three months I would get enough points to redeem for $150 in gift cards. After making sure the gift cards were to places I would actually use, I applied. I planned to get a Best Buy gift card but ended up doing Walmart. The gift card options really are varied enough that you don’t regret not getting cash back too much, but I do prefer to get cash back in my rewards.  So after three months and $1000 I had to wait a month, but sure enough without me doing anything else, the points appeared in my account. I ‘bought’ the gift cards with the points and they arrived very quickly, in under a week. Otherwise, the Citi card rewards fall a little short of my Chase card, where you earn 5% rewards on things that change every three months, but often include restaurants, gas, or groceries. Nothing beats 5% on groceries, even when it’s not all the time. Still, I found the Citi Thank you card was a nice alternative. It was accepted almost everywhere (Stupid Sam’s Club) and customer service was excellent and friendly.

name: Benjy Saloman
review: The Sunoco Credit Card has a variable APR, but only lists the regular rate of 16.99%. Like always I am wary of variable rates, especially when the range is not listed. I also don't see the max penalty listed. Getting rewards for spending money on Sunoco gas is a nice perk. However, it all depends on how prevalent Sunoco gas stations are where you live or are traveling. A company like Shell has more locations, but looking at their credit card, I see an APR of 23.99%. That is simply awful and of course it is variable, so it could go even higher.   You would be better off with a Sunoco card in that case. Frankly, I think in most cases you probably are just better off paying cash unless you are planning a long road trip.

name: chris
review: The Staples card has been a, well, staple of my purchasing for awhile now.  Like a lot of these store type cards, the interest rate is generally pretty high so it definitely doesn't pay to carry a balance, but there are more than enough benefits to using it that makes it worthwhile to pay off your balance each month.  The flat 5% off your purchases is worth it, even if you are not a frequent staples shopper.  it's a great card to use to save some money and use as a credit score booster by paying off your small purchases each month.

name: David Lawson
review: I've had my Staples card for about a year now. I love Staples, you can get some great deals there, so I decided to apply for a card. The application process was fairly quick and I had my card in a little over a week.  I'm happy to have the convenience of the card, and I like that you automatically receive staples rewards.  It doesn't have any outrageous fees, providing you do the right thing. However, as some others have pointed out, the rate is a bit high, so I don't generally like to carry a balance on it for too long. But like all credit, use it wisely, do the right thing, and you'll be OK. So far I haven't had any problems.

name: M H
review: The Best Buy credit card has average rewards for a store card.  The interest rate is better than my Officemax and Walmart cards.  My Walmart card’s cash advance rate is cheaper and the rewards are better and more flexible.  This card would be good for someone who shops almost exclusively at Best Buy for electronics, but would not be ideal for anyone else.  I tend to shop around for electronics and am not loyal to any one store, so this card wouldn’t have many benefits for me.  I also do not like that the max penalty APR is so much higher than the regular rate.

name: Pat Esswayne
review: Now this Shell Credit Card here's a gas card with some interesting caveats, so you should pay careful attention to how they reward you. You earn cash back on everyday stuff, though I'm not sure how much, so that's troubling. Then, of course, the gas rewards, which stipulates that you need to purchase $500 or more in one billing cycle, in order to gain 10 cents off per gallon up to 100 gallons for the next cycle. The max earn is 20 cents though, so maybe if you spend more? I would recommend this only if you're planning on paying very regularly with this, and you desperately need the gas discount as you're a heavy fuel consumer. And of course, read the fine print, because who knows what the actual rewards are on this card.

name: Pat Esswayne
review: So basically the only thing I'm seeing worthwhile here would be for the monthly sales events. I have a Kohl's card which acts in the same way (I wouldn't have and use it otherwise), so there must be something to the sales events that makes this card worthwhile. Because if you look at it, there's really nothing else going for this card, at all. Really, it's quite basic, though I suppose no liability on fraud is okay. People below are reporting good savings that aren't really specified in the above breakdown, so I'll have to side with them and say that these savings are worthwhile if you shop at the listed stores frequently.

name: chris
review: The Shell Gas Card is probably the most horribly named, yet still useful, credit card I've ever used.  It has nothing to do with gas, and I don't think I've ever used it at a Shell station.  What it is good for is all the aspects of travel /except/ gas.  Off the bat, it has a $25 annual fee, so if you dont see yourself using it a lot it might not be a good fit.  If you book a lot of airfare, or stay in a lot of hotels, you can really get a lot of savings using this card.  Just make sure you pay it off quickly, as the high interest rates can really ding you.  Just think about it not as a card to buy things you can't afford, but as a way to spend less money when you pay your bill in 30 days.

name: Michael M
review: Having to visit Staples a lot and purchasing supplies I needed, I found out they have a Staples Store Card. This came in very handy because unlike many Store Cards, this one gives you 5% off your purchases. This is really great for me because I have high taxes in my area, so what a great way to save a bit of money when I shop at Staples. The Staples Store card also has no annual fee, which is great. The interest rate is higher at 27.99% but if you pay the full balance off every month, it is not a big issue. If you do a lot of shopping at Staples, I highly recommend you pick up the store card  just for the 5% off.

name: Chantel Lynn
review: The ExxonMobil Credit Card certainly is ideal for buying gas. If you buy a lot of gas and are constantly traveling for work or pleasure, then you would benefit from this card. The card offers 15 cents per gallon back for gas purchases at Exxon/ Mobil stations and 2% on purchases elsewhere; that is a pretty good return for gas! I also like that the card can be used almost anywhere because it might come in handy when you least expect it (but need it)!  The interest rates are right in line with other MasterCard programs I have used in the past. I would most definitely recommend this card!

name: Chantel Lynn
review: The Goodyear Store card has a few good and a few bad qualities. I think the interest rates are a bit higher compared to other store cards I have used, my wal-mart store card is around 22%. I also think the network is limited as the card can only be used at a goodyear store. Furthermore, Goodyear only offers products in one specific market; therefore the card is really not that much of a convenience to have. There is no annual fee, no over limit charge and a cash advance option which are all good things, but are also pretty common among credit cards. Overall, I would prefer a card that could be used more widely rather than at just one store.

name: Pat Esswayne
review: As far as credit cards go, the Citi Simplicity Card looks excellent. No late fees, penalty rates, annual fees, and a 0% intro APR that might not go over 13% depending on your credit score. But this all depends on your credit score, because you need a really good one to get the card. But if you can snag it, this card looks very promising. I don't have very much experience with cards of this caliber, so I would say it blows anything I've heard about out of the water. If you're looking for all the best features from a credit card without the setbacks, and you have a great credit score, this one is definitely worth looking into.

name: Chris
review: The AT&T Credit Card is your average run of the mill rewards card. In fact, it is probably less than average. You get 10% off the purchase of products from AT&T, which for me isn't very useful. Also, because of the point system the reward program uses, you can only redeem it for so many things. The gift cards are nice, but I would prefer cash. Most of the gift cards aren't ones I would choose anyway. This card isn't really worth having, especially if you can get a better rewards card. But there's no annual fee, so why not I guess.

name: Randy Perreault
review: This card seems like a decent card... especially if you shop at Brooks Brothers often.  There don't seem to be any ridiculous fees and I like the point system they have.  They seem to offer nice incentives.  I think I would apply for this card if I shopped at this store.  I mean, 2,000 points would be easy to achieve, and I really like the $20 off birthday and anniversary too.  I think this is worth looking into.

name: Pat Esswayne
review: The Radio Shack Store Card seems okay. It's basically a rewards store card, much like any other, so if you shop at Radio Shack a bunch, it's worth it. For anyone else though, why bother. High APR, and nothing else that stands out as beneficial. But like I said, if you shop there, the rewards might be nice. I don't have all the details on the rewards, but they might be worthwhile, though I personally wouldn't buy batteries from Radio Shack. My experience with store cards is that you want to sign up for them only if you use that store quite a bit, and the rewards are worth it to you. Like with my Kohl's store card, the rewards from their bonus sales add up to quite a bit of savings, so definitely worth it. Your mileage may vary.

name: Chris
review: The Tire Kingdom Store Card is a good store card for getting tires when money may be low and you need them right away. The no annual fee, and no other fees attached to this card makes it very attractive option for purchasing tires from Tire Kingdom. There is also no interest charged if you pay the full amount within 6 months I believe. This coupled with low monthly payments makes this a great card to have to choose from. You may be able to save more by using a good rewards card, but if that isn't an option, consider getting this one.

name: Chris
review: The Expedia Credit Card is a good card for earning points towards flights and what not. You gain some points for every purchase you make through them and it adds up quickly. This card is not that great, it does not hold up to other cards in this category. The rewards are not as high as some other cards, and the customer service is kind of suspect. Overall, if you can get approved for some of the better rewards cards you will save more in the short term and long term, but those cards can be quite the pain to get approved for.

name: Chris
review: The Citi Secured Credit Card is another credit building or rebuilding card. The problem with secured cards is that most of them have lots and lots of ridiculous fees attached that never seem to end. They suffer from horrible customer service when you need it, and generally are just unreliable. Not with the Citi secured master card though. There is a $29.00 annual fee, but other than that, it is the only downside. Fantastic customer service. No monthly maintenance fees, or fees to use the card. Also it's from a reputable brand that you can trust. It's a great card for establishing your credit.

name: Chris
review: The Staples Store Card is great if you find yourself shopping at staples on a regular basis, or even sporadically. Just by being a member you save a fantastic 5% on all purchases with this card at staples. There is no ridiculous fees and not even an annual fee either. Another benefit on this card is how easy it is to get approved for it. Just apply and most likely you will get approved unless your credit is very very bad, and even then you still might get approved. There is also other benefits with being in the Staples reward program as well. This card is great for those people that shop at Staples quite often. Highly recommended.

name: Chris
review: The L.L.Bean Credit Card is much more than just a store card. It's actually a pretty good rewards card as well. You gain 3% on everything you buy at LL Bean, and 1% on everything you buy anywhere else. It's actually pretty good rates. The APR isn't as bad as some other cards, and there is no annual fee. You do need good credit to get approved for it, but that usually goes with most decent credit cards these days. There is also some exclusive sales only available to cardholders at LL bean, which is a nice added benefit on being a member. A great card if you shop at LL bean.

name: Joseph Plummer
review: The Citi Forward card is my favorite card. The main reason for this is I get 5 points for every $1 spent on amazon.com. Since I do nearly all my shopping on Amazon, no card is better. Even the official Amazon card only offers 3 points per $1 spent. The Citi Forward card also gives 5 points per dollar at restaurants! Since it is a Citi card, you can redeem your points for pretty much anything with Citi rewards. There are plenty of gift cards that pay $1 per 100 points, which is practically the best you can find anywhere. All in all, this card definitely gets the most use from me. Customer service is fantastic as well. They've raised my limit without asking and someone is available to answer the phone almost immediately anytime I've had to call them. I don't have a single negative thing to say about this card.

name: Michelle Fields
review: This looks like a slightly worse-than-average rewards card, unless you're a hardcore AT&T customer. You don't get any extra points for paying for your AT&T purchases with this card, but you DO get a 10% discount on them, which in all honesty is probably the better deal. The lack of an annual fee is nice, and the intro rate & ongoing rate for purchases are about average. My beef with this type of card is that, because your rewards accumulate in the form of points rather than actual cash, you are limited in what you can redeem for. While there is a decent selection of gift cards available, none of them are Visa or Amex type (at least as of this writing), meaning that you will always be limited to a single store. There's also the disadvantage, when redeeming for items other than gift cards, of the fact that your redemption is pretty much pegged to a penny per point, and there's no way to get a discount on the item. But maybe that only bothers me because I'm a hardcore bargain shopper, who rarely pays full price for anything. :)

name: Chris
review: The Radio Shack Store Card isn't a bad card but I probably don't need it. I do find myself shopping at Radio shack quite often, but the discount just isn't good enough to make you use this card. That is if you have another half decent rewards credit card that gives cash back. The discount for buying batteries is nice, and if you are planning on spending quite a bit there, then maybe it would be worth it to use this card, As you get no interest on purchases if you pay it off within 6 months I believe. It's a good store card, but might be replaced if you have another rewards credit card.

name: Chris
review: The Brooks Brothers Credit Card is a good card if you find yourself shopping at brooks brothers quite often. The rewards program offered for shopping with this card in the store is pretty good. You receive 4 points for every $1.00 spent at Brooks Brothers and 1 point for every $1.00 spent anywhere else. There's no ridiculous fee's and there is also no annual fee attached to the card. If you use the card for shopping at brooks brothers, you also receive free shipping on any items you choose to return to the store, which is a very nice bonus. Overall this is a good rewards store credit card for brooks brothers.

name: Chris
review: The Citi Diamond Preferred Card is a pretty good card, it is not one of my go to cards because I have some other good rewards cards that give great cash back, as this isn't one of them, it's hard to justify its use. Other than that, the no annual fee, and great customer service, not to mention decent rates and some other features the card offers makes this very attractive. It is kind of hard to get approved for though, and I'm not really sure why. Seeing as hard it is to get approved for it, you would think it would be better. But it is a good card though, if you can get it.

name: Michael M
review: The Sunoco Credit Card is a great reward card to have if you visit a lot of Sunoco locations. This credit card rewards you if you buy gallons of gas at any Sunoco locations with extra bonus points. This lets you quickly stack up your ThankYou Points to redeem various rewards, a great feature that I like a lot. You can also earn 1 ThankYou Point for every $1 you spend, I like that the Sunoco Credit Card gives you multiple ways to earn points. Another great feature about this card is that it does not have a annual fee, which is a huge plus from me as I hate owning cards that charge you a fee for just having it. Interest rate for the Sunoco Credit Card is reasonable for a rewards card, as I usually see them around 24.9% APR. If you buy lots of gas and visit Sunoco, I highly recommend this Credit Card for all the rewards you can build up quickly.

name: Chris
review: The Citi Forward Card is a great rewards card to have, especially if you like to eat out a lot and buy books and the sort. The rewards definitely add up and you can save quite a bit from using this card on a regular basis. I just found out that Amazon counts as a bookstore so, yea that's amazing. I usually buy my books from amazon so I wish I knew that before. No annual fee, no other lame fees that aren't normally associated with credit cards. Great customer service, just an all around good card. It isn't that difficult to get approved for either. Highly recommended!

name: Michael M
review: If you need a travel based credit card, then look no further than the Shell Gas Card. This card offers amazing bonuses for using it during traveling and booking, such as a discount and 10% cash back for staying at an approved hotel. This card also offers 5% discounts on airline tickets and car rentals, which is great for saving money.  Finally the Shell Gas Card offers an emergency $1,000 cash or prepaid airline ticket. For travel this card is great to have, but beware of the annual fee of $25, one of the negatives to the Shell Gas Card. It also has a high interest rate and 29.95% cash advance, so be sure to pay off the amounts very quickly. If you do a lot of traveling or vacations, then I highly recommend it, do not be confused because it has the word "gas" in it!

name: Nick Martocello
review: One of the worst possible choices for a credit card possible, you're really better off having any credit card besides the Goodyear Store Card. No annual feel is great, but most cards already have this. It offers discounts and promotions, great? It seems more like one of those rewards cards you use to see if you get discounts on groceries but get kicked with a super high APR. Sure you can pay it online, but every credit card has that feature. I would highly recommend staying away from this card, it brings nothing to to the table. You can find better else where!

name: Owen
review: The Citi Simplicity Credit Card is as simple as it gets. It's great for someone with minimal but great credit. It's also especially great for someone who doesn't use credit all the time. If you just want to build credit by paying a bill or two a month with it, it's great. There's no interest for the first year and a half, and there's no hidden fees! That's awesome. Those yearly membership fees on other cards get really annoying. It's great that there's no late or penalty fee (just the expected increased APR%). This card is exactly what it states- Simplicity.

name: Nick Martocello
review: Good card to save on gas,  $0.15 per gallon on eligible gasoline purchases made at Exxon and Mobil stations 2% on other purchases. So as you see the Exxon Mobil Credit Card is pretty much good for saving up on gas. If you travel a lot it would be a good investment to make, get a save a little while spending. This would definitely be a good card to have to get some savings, if you don't already have a cash back credit card such as the Capitol One Quiksilver.

name: Alex Brokaw
review: As someone searching for my first credit card, I found the Citi Simplicity Card to be ideal for me.  Having a credit card can be terrifying but the Citi Simplicity Card does what it’s intended to do: make things simple.  The intro period allowed me to ease into the process of learning how to use a credit card, without charging interest. I wish the interested rate (mine being 18%) was lower but I feel that is competitive with other cards. The fact that there are no late fees or annual fees is great added bonus. I wish this card offered some sort of rewards program but otherwise I have no complaints.  I have had any issues with this card and would recommend this card to anyone applying for their first credit card.

name: Meg
review: LL Bean Visa, managed by Barclay Bank, is a great credit card.  By offering free shipping and free return shipping from LL Bean, this helps a lot in ordering on-line.  The bonus coupons are a plus, too.  Customer Service is terrific.  I once had a bogus charge and I received a call at 7am alerting me to the unauthorized use of my card.  Barclay’s immediately cancelled the card and issued me a new one on the spot.  On-line account access is a breeze and transactions are noted promptly.  I would recommend this card to anyone who shops at LL Bean.  Two thumbs up!

name: Alyssa Hancock
review: The Shell card is an extremely useful card to own. Every credit card has its ups and downs, but with this card you get many benefits such as money towards gas, groceries. and many other things. The great part is  that you get bonuses when you use this card towards gas purchases which is a plus compared to other credit cards! With gas prices skyrocketing like they have been, it's nice to have a card that will give you money back towards more fuel-ups. I would definitely recommend this card if there are lots of Shell stations around your house or your job because otherwise it won't be as convenient a card for you. I have lots of Shell stations near me, so this card was a great investment for me.

name: Chris
review: The Best Buy Credit Card is pretty good, I've stopped using it because I don't go to best buy much anymore as the prices just aren't as low as some online retailers. But the card itself is very good. You get basically 5% cash back on purchases in the store, which is very good if you do not have any other rewards credit cards yet. No annual fee makes this attractive as well. It also lets you finance various high priced items for up to two years I believe. Which is a nice feature. Overall the card is a pretty decent card, nothing spectacular but it is good.

name: Owen
review: I've really reaped the benefits of my Sears credit card. I am an automotive technician, and although I get vendor's soliciting their tools, I prefer Sears for a variety of reasons. My loyalty extended after I got the credit card and I'm now able to take full advantage of additional discounts, savings on interest, and also by using this credit card at other eligible stores. I get rewarded for my loyalty with additional great savings, both at Sears and at the other stores. Their interest rates are more than fair and their customer service is definitely top notch. I had a minor issue a few months back and they fixed it very promptly above and beyond my satisfaction.

name: Chris
review: I've had the Home depot Store card for years, and I absolutely love it. I'm always doing home repairs and fixing various things around the house. When ever something breaks or needs updating I'm the guy to call. Being able to go to home depot and buy what I need, without having to pay immediately is very nice. Especially since if you pay off the bill within 6 months there is no interest charged! I love this little card and I use it quite often. I highly recommend the Home Depot store card if you spend a lot on home repairs stuff a lot.

name: erin fanshier
review: I am back in school as a student for a second degree, and it has been helpful for me to use this card as a student. Since I am a little older than a first time college student it was easier to be responsible with money and use this card to help build my credit. I really liked the 'thank you points,' and it was helpful for me to use this card while in school and working a part-time job, especially when I was short at the end of the month and needed the reassurance of some extra money to help with books and tuition related costs.

name: Steve Zaleski
review: The AT&T Credit Card is the perfect choice for any current/potential AT&T customers. The 10% discount of AT&T products/services is extremely beneficial especially if you plan on upgrading your current phone. You also receive a gratuitous amount of bonus Thank You points where you can buy almost anything; or just settle for a gift card. It's a great card with a lot of excellent incentives for using it. The only main flaw is that there is no introductory interest rate which differs from the 10 month introductory rate I am familiar with a Discover student card. Other than that, I highly recommend it!

name: donald pietrowski
review: I am not a huge fan of the Shell Gas Card terms and conditions. This is due, in part, to the fact that it requires an annual $25 fee. Almost all the cards that I possess do not have any fees. I feel very strongly about this and probably wouldn't use the Shell Gas Card for that reason. However, I do like the flat rate $35 max late fee. The rewards you earn using this card also seem to be more generous than other rewards programs that I have seen.I especially like the 50% discount at over 5,000 hotels and 30% discount at many more.

name: William Reyes
review: The Citi Secured Credit Card is a great offer for those wanting to start building a great credit score. Compared to my U.S Bank credit card, this Citi card offers a lot more features, such as depositing an amount into a CD (Earning 1.01% annually.), and that amount becomes your card limit for your convenience. In addition, you can become an unsecured card holder after 18 months, to enjoy more freedom while spending. The regular interest rate is average, but it is tolerable. The annual fee is very low, and you have $0 liability for charges you did not authorize, in addition to Citi identity theft protections. Plus, when you rent a vehicle, you can be covered in case of an accident just by using this card!

name: William Reyes
review: The Citi Platinum Select / AAdvantage World MasterCard Credit Card for those who want more freedom, and exciting perks and rewards. Compared to the United Mileage Plus credit card, this one offers a lot more miles to start with, such as the 30k miles in the beginning. It also helps that they wave the first year of annual fees, and you earn 10% of your already redeemed miles, up to 10,000 a year. You always get your first bag checked in for free, and the interest rate is not too high. You also get discounts with several purchases, and with each membership renewal. I would recommend this card to frequent travelers!

name: Albert Phan
review: The National Tire & Battery (NTB) Store Card is a pretty run of the mill store card. If you're buying a lot of products from this chain, then I'd check this card out. There's no rewards, but you can get a $50 Visa Prepaid Card on purchases of $399 or more, or $25 card for $199 or more. There's no interest if paid in 12 months, but you need to make a payment of at least $799. There's store benefits with special rebate/coupon offers and low monthly payments. This is definitely on par with other cards such as Big O Tires Store Card, but the only different is that the prepaid cost tiers are different with a range of $100. So get this card if you're buying a lot of car products from this chain.

name: Albert Phan
review: If you're planning on going to or a frequent buyer of Big O Tires, then the Big O Tires Store Card is a card that's definitely worth checking out. Although there are no rewards, purchases and cash advances are on par with other cards, it has its perks by having special rebate/coupon offers, special financing, and low monthly payments for frequent buyers. There's no balance transfers and you also need to spend $250 or $500 minimum to get great benefits. Comparing this to the National Tire and Battery Store Card, Big O has higher rates that you need to clear compared to the NTB, such as NTB having a $200 minimum and Big O having $250. This is a last resort card and I wouldn't recommend it at all.

name: Nathan Gerard
review: I have had my citi dividend platinum card since 2004 when I first started applying for credit cards.  I have opened other accounts and then closed them and it seems like this citi card has always been reliable.  Anytime that I have had to call customer service they were very nice and I was able to understand them well.  They resolved my issue in a timely matter.  I haven’t noticed that citi has played any tricks as far as billing or interest rates.  When my card was getting close to getting maxed out I tried to raise my credit limit and they let me do that after checking my credit with no problem.  This credit card also has a nice rewards program attached to it.  I would recommend this card.  You can earn up to 5% on certain items, that is really good.

name: Albert Phan
review: If you're a frequent customer of AT&T through their many services, then the AT&T Credit card would probably benefit you the most. The Reward bonus for signing up is great with 10,000 points with a base/max earn rate of 1 point/$1. This card basically rewards you with shopping within AT&T and the ThankYou Bonus Center with gift cards and other amenities.  In regards to the purchase, balance transfers, and cash advances, it's on par with all the other cards, with only the reward bonus being something different and beneficial to the customer. There's also automatic travel insurance and $0 liability on unauthorized charges. In comparison to Capital One's Quicksilver Cash Rewards Credit Card, the purchases, balance transfers, and cash advances are on par, but the Capital One Card has a percentage based earn and a lifetime 1.5% cash back on every purchase. The $100 signing bonus is a plus too. Overall, I'd get the AT&T Credit Card if you're on a AT&T Mobile Plan to make life easier.

name: Darrell Brown
review: This card is good for people that are in areas where there are some exxon/mobil gas stations. There is no downside to owning the ExxonMobile gas card and I like that it takes 6 cents off the price of gas. The minimum gas per month shouldn't be easily exceeded especially if you work a regular full time job so that's not a big issue. I also like that it has $0 fraud liability on unauthorized charges just in case someone steals your card and goes on an gas spending spree. The interest rate is high at 24.99% but the 25 day grace period should see to it that you don't incur interest if you pay your bills on time. I currently use a Sam's club credit card that saves me an average between 4-5 cents on gas but doesn't require a minimum amount of gas to be bought each month which I like.

name: Justin Parker
review: The Brooks Brothers credit card is a solid choice for a store credit card.  The initial bonus point reward of 15% is on par with similar store cards and the bonus point earning is very generous at 4 points per dollar spent at Brooks Brothers.  This card is very similar to the Banana Republic Visa card that I have used in the past.  Both have the same initial 15% bonus, although Banana Republic gives the 15% to you immediately off your first purchase instead of loading the card with points.  The Banana Republic card does offer more maximum points (5) if you shop at any of the Gap family of stores.  That being said, the Brooks Brothers card potentially offers more “free money,” which I like, since it rewards you with two $20 discount cards per year for your birthday and, if you are married, for your anniversary.  The reward structure is slightly different between the two cards:   you have to accumulate 2,000 points with the Brooks Brothers card to receive a $20 discount, whereas the Banana Republic card rewards you more quickly with a $10 discount after 1,000 points.  The Brooks Brothers card has a significantly better APR, varying between 14% and 24% depending on your credit worthiness, while the Banana Republic card is fixed at 23%, no matter how good your credit is.  In my opinion, this potentially lower APR and the extra $40 in discounts gives the Brooks Brothers the edge as far as these two store cards go.

name: M H
review: The Citi Platinum Select AAdvantage World Mastercard has an average interest rate compared to other prime cards.  I have a better interest rate with my Bank of America rewards card while also having much more flexible rewards in the form of cash back.  The rewards of this card are great for people who travel a lot, which doesn't apply to most people.  The cash advance rate and fee for this card is more expensive than most other prime cards as well and is similar to sub-prime cards such as Capital One rewards card.  Overall this could be a good card for someone who travels extensively, but the benefits of other prime cards would result in greater savings for the majority of people.

name: Nick Martocello
review: The Big O Tires Store Card is maybe the perfect card for you, but most likely not. You wont really be getting much out of it unless youre having tons of tire issues weekly or monthly. But who really has that issue. You get prepaid visa cards if you pay a select amount and a high % rate for fees. If you buy tires you get 6 months interest free to pay them off. You would be better off using a gas card for the most park like Quik or NEA or general cash rewards card and just build your points off of spending it on the repairs and tires.My opinion would to be stray away from it and get a Chase Rewards or Visa Rewards card.

name: John Peterson
review: If your like me and often need tires or car repairs done but just don't have the cash at the exact time you need it, you really need to look into the National Tire & Battery Store Card. Although its geared toward folks with good to excellent credit it can really help you out if  your in a bind and can get it. The main downside is that it has a very high APR even for a store card, 28.99% is a little crazy.  Other than the high APR is a great card that offers feature like no interest if paid with in 6 months and no annual fee.

name: Chris
review: The Shell Gas Card is kind of interesting, or confusing one might say, unless you really read what you are getting. You would think, since it's a Shell Gas Card, you would get some kind of cash back or rewards for purchasing gas, but nope. Nothing. In fact, it isn't even useful in any way at a Shell gas station, which makes no sense. Either way, this card is great if you do lots of traveling and spend a lot on hotels and car rentals. The money back is actually very high, it's just quite misleading to call it a Gas card, when it most obviously isn't one.

name: Edward David
review: When it comes to secured credit cards to help build up your credit so you can get those fancy cards with the benefits, the Citi Secured Credit Card is actually pretty good. The card's APR is going to be high with 18% but there's not much you can do when you have terrible credit, and thats why you're using this card. It requires a $200 deposit to get the card so if you default they get that money. After a year to 18 months, you get reviewed for a chance at a credit card thats unsecured. This will report monthly to the major bureaus and help you get that credit rating back on track.

name: Pat Esswayne
review: This AT&T Credit Card seems like a standard run-of-the-mill rewards card, good for those who use AT&T. If you have AT&T for phone or internet service, then the initial 10% savings for the first year is great, and the 5% after that seems decent as well. The rewards themselves seem standard, as compared to other rewards cards, including the Amazon rewards card I use. However, I'd have to look up the specifics of the rewards program to see if it's worthwhile. The APR seems competitive and standard, and the $0 unauthorized charge liability is a plus as well.

name: Ben
review: If you're a daily commuter to and from work, the ExxonMobil Gas Card is probably one of the better gas station cards. I drive quite a bit to get to my work, then quite a bit to get back home when I'm off. That adds up to trips to the pump rather quickly! And with this ExxonMobil Gas Card, I'd earn 6 cents from every gallon - about 1.5% back in the current economy. Granted, compared to the TrueEarnings from Costco and American Express, which offers a stunning 3% cash back, this card pales a bit, but there's no annual fee. I'd keep an eye on that 24.99% APR, but other than that, this is better than anything offered by CITGO or Chevron!

name: Edward David
review: If you shop with Brooks Brothers this card isn't that bad. I always love rewards programs and that's what they give you. 4 points per $1 is pretty good compared to most reward credit cards, the standard seems to be just double, being only 2 points so its definitely one upping other places. It also only requires 2000 points for your first gift card too which is a bit lower than other places. A really cool bonus though is that every year you get a $20 birthday card and a $20 anniversary card from them. That is definitely one thing which is above and beyond most cards. They give you something cool which most don't and actually make you want to shop there.

name: Edward David
review: This card makes absolutely no sense to have. When you get a gas card you expect to get money back from that gas station, but nope this doesn't give you that. You get money back from actually renting hotels from various across the country. What makes even less sense is that you get money back from buying airline tickets? Why would they want to give you that if its a shell card. They would want you to drive everywhere since they can sell you more gasoline. This card just makes no sense, and has no reason to get it. I was highly disappointed with this card because i wanted money back for buying gas at the local station.

name: stephen blackwell
review: The Citi ThankYou Premier Card offers competitive rates starting as low as 13.99%, which is very reasonable for a card such as this. The rewards program is the main draw here, though, as you earn extra points for the things you shop for the most, such as gas, groceries and more. The personal concierge service is also a nice draw for those that are very busy. This card fell just out of my credit range when I was looking at cards I was interested in, but it was very high on my list. I settled for the Capital One Quicksilver Card but this was the card that I truly wanted. I would recommend this card to anyone who has a use for a credit card on a semi-regular basis.

name: Reylin Bates
review: The Radio Shack Store Card is a really good card to have. It is decent and for those of you that shop at Radio Shack, it can come in handy. I like that you do not need amazing credit to get it and also that there is no annual fee. That is always a good thing. Now they do have decent rewards, but i dislike that the rewards are a bit stale. Any discount is great. Don't get me wrong, saving money is lovely, but compare to other store cards such as the Best Buy card, the rewards aren't that great. A nice perk to this card is that you can get 15% off of store-stocked batteries.

name: Reylin Bates
review: The Big O Tires Store Card is a good option for a few people, but not all. It is good for those select few of you that has tire issues very often. I do like that there is no interest if paid in full within 6 months, but I would not get this card. They also have a nice $50 cash back, so that is a plus. I, personally, this getting this type of card is a waste but it could come in handy for some people. I would go with a gas card like NEA instead since you actually use gas a lot.

name: Ben
review: The National Tire & Battery Store Card is like most other store cards - they're good only if you shop at the store often. Given the fact this store sells tires and batteries, I'm not sure how often I would visit here. However, seeing as how it offers no interest rate when you make purchases over certain minimums for several months, I can definitely see the attraction to this card. Plus it offers cash back as a prepaid Visa when buying tires. Overall, however, the card has a shocking APR of 28.99%! I would much rather consider the Bed Bath & Beyond Credit Card, not only because I'm more likely to shop there, but the APR is lower and the card offers better benefits in terms of a rewards program.

name: Ben
review: When you're a frequent traveler, you need an airline card with the airline of your choice. So if you fly American Airlines often, then the Citi Platinum Select / AAdvantage World MasterCard Credit Card is great - offering a round-trip domestic flight for spending $1,000 in the first 3 months of owning this card. The other perks are fairly standard, like the 2 points/dollar bonus for spending money at American Airlines, and 1 point otherwise. And it lets you check on a bag for free, similar to the Southwest Airlines Rapid Rewards Credit Card. However, this card has a hefty $95 a year fee after the first year, so if you're not a frequent flyer on AA, this card could easily end up costing you more than you were looking for...

name: Jordan Webb
review: If you are an AT&T user, the AT&T Credit Card can be a great investment. This is one of the best company credit cards I’ve seen; the rewards program seems really great, and you can save up to 10% on AT&T services; those savings can add up fast for your phone, TV, and internet bills if you have these grouped altogether! However, the interest rate is mediocre, although there is a 0% rate for balance transfers for the first year. Because of the great rewards program, I would recommend this credit card for any AT&T user that wants to save!

name: Ben
review: Pay attention to what you're getting, and this is definitely a GREAT card. The Shell Gas Card doesn't offer any rewards for buying their gasoline, which I admit to be very strange. However, it does offer a whopping 10% cash back on a variety of hotels, which is a HUGE amount of cash back for anything! A business traveler would benefit greatly from this Shell Gas Card. And, to make it even sweeter, it offers 5% cash back on car rentals and airplane tickets! I think that actually might be even better than my Southwest Airlines Rapid Rewards Plus Credit Card. The TrueEarnings from Costco and American Express only offers 2% on travel, and costs at least $55 a year to maintain, whereas this is only $25. This card is a serious must-have for your wallet if you travel often.

name: David Bishop
review: As far as secured cards go, the Citi Secured Credit Card is rather typical, but does carry a decent rate on purchases. The annual rate isn't as bad as some, and the monthly/one times fees of...zero...is about as good as it gets. Also, with a plan to get an unsecured card after a year and a half, Citi provides an option of people with limited or bad history to build up their credit a little bit with this card. Also, the ability to earn some money on your CD is a feature that I was unaware of with other cards.

name: Edward David
review: I got this card expecting some bonus for buying my gas at the gas station down the road but instead they give you bonuses for going to hotels like the Ramada and Hilton. I dont even understand the Shell Gas Card AT ALL? Why would you be giving me money back for airline tickets when I'm trying to buy fuel for my car. Isn't rewarding me for airplanes like counterintutive because they should want me to drive isntead of fly? Please shell give me bonuses for buying gas not for hotels and stuff. This card also does not give me anything worth going to Shell and it makes me sad

name: Edward David
review: AT&T Credit Card is an alright card if they want to get bonuses through AT&T. The biggest bonus being able to receive a 10% discount on all AT&T products and services for the first 12 months, 5% after that. So if you have AT&T phone, internet, or other services through them, just using this card will give you money back and save you a bit. They also have a decent point system to pay out bonuses and rewards based on how much you spend. Every $1 spent on the card is 1 point and those points can be put towards a $100 gift card. No introductory rates is sad but that's the only major downside to the cards.

name: stephen blackwell
review: The ExxonMobil Gas Card would be a great addition to anyone's wallet, I believe. If you have to drive a lot to work and back or for anything else then it's a great card. You can ear up to 6 cents off every gallon of ExxonMobil gasoline that you put into your car. The 24.99% interest rate is a little worrying but provided you only spend it on gas, which is recommended, you can't really go wrong. I wish my current Capital One Quicksilver Visa Card had the gas rewards that this card does. I will be attempting to add this card to my wallet very soon!

name: Ben
review: If you shop at a tire store often, this can be good... but who does that, unless your tires are blowing out once a week The Big O Tires Store Card does offer a nice $50 prepaid visa back ... but how often is that? I think you might only get that cash back for shopping at Big O Tires! I own the Costco American Express, which offers a cash back percentage bonus, but this card doesn't seem to offer one. I'd probably stick to my current cards - but one thing you might want to know is that if you buy tires (I think it's tires) with this card, there's no interest for 6 months as you pay it back, which is very helpful. If you need tires, this card is great, but if you don't, use something else.

name: Ashley Ballard
review: The Radio Shack Store Card is pretty decent for people that frequently shop at Radio Shack. There is no annual fee, you earn discounts such as 10% or 15% off purchases and if you pay your balance in full within the first 6 months, there is no interest. It is similar to the Kohl's credit card as they also offer special discounts of 15-30% although they have no zero interest introductory offer. Neither of the cards have annual fees, but they both have high interest, ranging from 22% to 29%. It is best to pay your balance in full each month to avoid extra charges.

name: Mike Greiner
review: A great way to reduce your monthly phone bill is by signing up for an AT&T Credit Card.  By using this card to pay for your cell phone you can save 10% the first year and 5% every year thereafter.   It’s a category you don’t usually see such a high percent of cash back on.  Beyond that, this card gets the standard 1% back on your purchases you make everywhere else.  The biggest down fall to this card is that there is a limit to the amount of points you can earn at 50,000 which might make this a deal breaker for those that want to use this as their every day credit card.

name: Mike Greiner
review: The main benefits of the Shell gas card are kind of misleading, as there are little to no benefits using this card for gas purchases.  You’re going to see the main benefit if you are a frequent traveler and stay at hotels such as Holiday Inn, Hilton and Ramada.  You’ll get up to 10% cash back at major hotel chains, and 5% back on airlines and car rentals.  I would only recommend this card if you are a frequent traveler, as the $25 annual fee might set you back more than the rewards you’ll earn if you only stay at a hotel one or two nights per year.

name: Mike Greiner
review: If you have been applying for credit cards and are having trouble getting one due to your credit history you might want to consider the Citi Secured MasterCard.  It different than a prepaid credit card, as your credit limit is secured by the size of a deposit you are willing to put into a CD for 18 months.  This amount could be anywhere between $200-$500.  The upside to this card is that you will earn a 1% interest rate on your CD, which is better than a savings account.  But you will have to pay a $29 annual fee.  The main advantage of this card over a prepaid debit card is that you have protection against unauthorized charges, and if you lose your card you don’t lose all your money.

name: David Bishop
review: As seems about par for the course with rewards cards in my experience, the Brooks Brothers Credit Card offers no introductory rates on purchases or balance transfers, and the regular rates for both of these is about in line with other comparable cards. However, the foreign transaction fee is lower than many cards I have seen, and the max payout of 4 points per dollar spent for purchases made at Brooks Brothers is on the high-end of the spectrum as far as rewards programs go. So if you are someone who wants to use your credit card overseas occasionally and are a frequent customer at Brooks Brothers, then this card is definitely for you.

name: Nick Straka
review: The Citi ThankYou Premier card seems similar to a Citi Card that I already have, the AAdvantage Citi American Express. The bonuses that come with the card seem like a good deal, especially the bonus reward points after $3,000 in purchases. The only thing that deters me from looking further into this card is the somewhat steep annual fee. $125 is a bit more I currently pay for an annual fee on my current card. This offer actually seems like a pretty good deal and I might be more willing to apply for it if the fee was less.
