They are very knowledgeable and I have never had to speak with a manager for a problem because the customer service people can solve it before it gets to that point. It is really a breath of fresh air dealing with Citibank!

name: Yurel Cooke
review: I had a Citibank account for about two months. There is nothing special about this bank at all. Citibank may of been one of the best banks in the 1980's but it seems so outdated and behind the times. The customer service is very average and you never get off the phone feeling that you truly accomplished anything. Citibank needs to have a dramatic upgrade and get with the times. If you are a person that is interested in Citibank, then you need to strongly consider Chase, TD Bank or Bank of America. All of these banks are better than Citibank.

name: Evelin Hechmer
review: I started using Citibank about 8 years ago. My parents told me to get a credit card and only use it sparingly to accumulate some credit during college, which was about a year ago. I figured I would go ahead with what I know and get it through Citibank. I couldn’t be happier with the Citibank Platinum Visa. I got $100 back after buying my books at the beginning of the semester! I usually get about $10-30 a month from cash back, but it all really depends on how much I do that month. I use my credit card in lieu of cash only to accumulate a positive credit score, so I have never had any issues with Citi on that front, if you pay your maximum balance monthly, you will certainly have a pleasant experience like myself.

name: Kyle Belfort
review: This is a great credit card! Accepted everywhere and trusted by all. Has a pretty reasonable late fee and the grace period is nice. Best of all, my favorite thing about the card is that is I get benefits at the local L.L. Bean store. I love to shop there and this just encourages me to spend do what I love. Plus I get coupons automatically at L.L. Bean. Very useful. The 1% back feature is pretty sweet as well.

name: Marcel Hounchell
review: I have had the Sears Mastercard through CitiBank for the past 3 years. I have enjoyed having this credit card, not only am I able to use it for Sears and K-mart, but I can use it for anything. You even get some savings and occasional coupons for Sears or K-mart through use of the credit card. I have had nothing but good customer service when calling about any issues or questions with this card. I use this credit card often. The terms of this credit card are pretty reasonable. I am happy with my choice of this card.

name: Leah
review: I don’t use many credit cards but when I do, I use my Citibank Thank You credit card. I actually started using this credit card for everyday purchases, which I then I pay off immediately just to earn the mileage points. I enjoy earning mileage points that are redeemable for just about any travel expense. I also like the free companion airfare ticket. The only drawback I see is the $150 annual fee, though I’m grateful to be enjoying one year of no annual fees for signing up. In the future, I hope I earn enough points to warrant this fee.

name: Megan Mitchell
review: This is a good first time card. Nice 0% intro apr for 6 months. Interest rates are average thereafter. Card use is fairly universal with the visa logo. All bills paid on time I've had no trouble attaining credit increases. Interest is figured into your monthly payment not total balanced owed. Their website is always up and is easy to navigate. On a more superficial note the card has a cool design and you have a choice of color scheme. Overall I have enjoyed this card and used it quite frequently. I would definitely advise applying if you are a first time card holder.

name: Marc Wood
review: The best part about our Citibank Thank You credit card seems to be the 50,000 free points we received after making a few purchases. I love that we earn one mile for every $1.00 we put on the card. We also get one free airline ticket every year. The only down fall I see with the credit is the $150 annual fee. It has been waived for the first year, but I don’t know if the card will be worth keeping once the fee is tacked on. I know I like it now and I know I will like better once we redeem our first airline ticket.

name: Shannon Cutts
review: I love my Citibank Visa card. I never carry more than a few credit cards at one time, and this is in part because I don't want to have to manage several lines of credit, but mostly because Citibank has been so good to me that I have never felt the need to try out new credit cards, no matter how good the offers sound. I don't get perks with my Citibank Visa card the way I do with some of my Chase credit cards (airline miles, Amazon points, etc.) but I still consider my Citibank card to be my credit "rock". The few times I have had to do balance transfers they have always had an awesome zero interest balance transfer offer to give me, they have been super-helpful in answering my questions and helping me manage my credit line, and anytime I have had the occasional "oops" of going out of town and being late on a payment, for instance, they have always credited me back any late charges. I highly recommend this card!

name: Rei Allen
review: Citibank is great for me. Customer service is fast and excellent, ironing out (or at least figuring out) problems or confusion very quickly. I’ve never had a question or problem that Citibank’s staff didn’t examine or analyze with real diligence. At other banks in the past, I’ve often quickly been given some stock answer for my questions that doesn’t tell me anything, as if I were talking to a robot and not a person at all. For example, when I asked someone from my old bank about a transaction, they gave me a description of the transaction, like I couldn’t read that for myself. When I asked a similar question at Citibank, the staff took just a few clicks to explain when and where the transaction had occurred, without me having to start some kind of legal process before I’ve even decided that the transaction wasn’t me.  Also, Citibank’s rewards program is the only one that’s ever been simple enough and accessible enough (through online banking) that I’ve actually used it.

name: Rebecca Vinson
review: I am amazed at the customer service that this bank offers. I was having some difficulties with unauthorized debits to my account. They immediately began investigating it and cancelled my debit card. The very next day, I got a new debit card via UPS. There was no charge to my account for that, which was very nice. They also have great online customer service chat available if you cannot speak for whatever reason. I have used it three times so far, and each time the person was quick and professional. They answered my questions and even directed me to links where I could find more information. This bank goes above and beyond the typical with their customer service.

name: Jana Lee
review: I've been with Citibank for about 10 years now, and have had nothing but great experiences with them. The checking account I have is simple and does not involve a ton of unnecessary fees or hidden charges. I find the company very easy to deal with, and their customer service has always been helpful and courteous. I've had an identity theft issue in the past, and Citibank helped me resolve not only issues with their company, but gave me advice on how to handle disputes with other companies! Overall, I've found that Citibank goes out of its way to keep their customers satisfied, and I would recommend this bank to anyone.

name: stephen nick
review: I have always cherished my association with CitiBank . It is indeed a customer’s dream to have such kind of banking where you are offered all kind of services. The banking staff is extremely responsive and lets things go easier your way. No need to wait for longer hours and waste your precious time, just contact them via cell phone, e- mail or online customer support service and get instant help. I have been their customer for the last two years and enjoying the credit card facility too. I think my money is in really safe hands. I have bank statement available online for easy reference and record. Their loan policy is also attractive but I yet did not apply for that. Surely, I would do that in case I need money at some stage of my life. Highly trustable bank for all.

name: Rocco Hosta
review: I just received this card, which I wanted mainly for the balance transfer rate. At 0% for 18 months, it gives me plenty of time to pay off some of my larger balances that I'm currently carrying on other cards at 15-20%. The Simplicity also has a 0% purchase APR for the first 18 months as well. Other than that, there's no bells and whistles to this card. No rewards, though they are pretty lenient on things like late fees and over-limit penalties.I'd recommend it especially to someone looking for a first card. With a long interest free period, it's a great way to learn to use credit properly, without falling victim to interest charges and the nickel-and-diming that often comes along with "entry-level" credit cards. Overall a good, hassle-free, no-frills credit card.

name: WalletHub
review: Rocco, thanks for your recommendation but most first time credit card users won't be able to qualify since this card requires excellent credit.

name: Shelly Chalace
review: The Citi Dividend Platinum Select credit card is awesome. I got it one day at a showcase on campus. It is my first credit card and I am really enjoying it. I love that I can earn money back on my purchases.  I mainly use the card to make gas purchases and emergencies to avoid high interest rates and also to build credit. The only problem I have ever had was when I was charged two times for a purchase. I called customer service and they were really nice and everything was taken care of immediately.  I definitely recommend this card.

name: Jessica
review: The first credit card I ever applied for was through Citi, and now that I look back at all of the credit traps an 18 year old can fall for I am grateful that I fell into the right hands. I still have the same Citi card, though the company has since changed the type of card that I have and offered me further bonuses and thank you points that I wasn’t originally up for. When the recession began years ago my husband and I both had trouble finding work. Citi granted my husband six months of payment relief while he found work, and then set him up on a low payment plan after that. When I called and asked Citi for help they explained to me that I didn’t have enough debt to require their relief, but instead of just denying my claim the representative took the time to reassure me that my credit situation is doing just fine, and I simply didn’t need their services. They lowered my payment for that month and were ready to help me in ways they could. When I hung up the phone with the Citi representative that day I actually felt better after talking with my credit card company, and I know that is pretty rare. I plan on holding onto my Citi card for a long time.

name: Bob Hanson
review: This is a really great card. I pay off the balance each month so it works great for me. Once, I did not receive my bill and did not pay the bill. After being assessed charged, in accordance with the user agreement, I contact their customer service. They apologized for the mistake and assured me the the bills would come through in the future. They also removed the fee they had previously charged. Overall, it is a great card. Honestly, most cards are pretty similar but the excellent customer service that comes with this card made it rise above the rest, in my estimation.

name: Heather Weaver
review: I first got the Citi Forward card when I was in university. The card has definitely served me quite well. I got a decent credit limit, the first 6 months had no interest and I have definitely enjoyed the rewards/points you can earn. It has been a fantastic first credit card. It’s helped me to build up my credit score and I’ve been able to responsibly use the card. It’s not too expensive and there aren’t any fees other than interest/late charges so that’s definitely quite nice, since I’m still not making a lot of money. All in all, it’s a pretty decent credit card. As the reviewer below me said, it does a lot of things fairly well but nothing exceptionally well.

name: Aaron Crossman
review: This card has done what we wanted it to.  We love the rewards.  The black color is pretty sweet, and it is great to have them as a credit provider.  Once, our number was stolen, and they called us to tell us that there were unauthorized transactions, and they took care of everything.  We just love, love, love it.  I am so thankful that they provided me the opportunity to write this review.  GO CITICARD!

name: Chelee McKenna
review: I recently got the Citi Thank You Rewards card with the 25,000 bonus points when you spend $2,000 in the first 4 months. The 25,000 bonus points can be used to get a $250 gift card of your choice. At first I was skeptical that we would actually get the 25,000 bonus points but lo and behold when last statement came out they were on there. I feel great knowing that I am earning one point for every $1 spent and that I can use it towards gift cards. We use credit cards anyway why not get rewarded for it. Great card to use and I can not wait to cash in my bonus points and get my gift card. I think we are going to go with the Longhorn gift certificate and even though it's a steakhouse, $250 is going to go a long, long way.

name: Lindsay Weigand
review: This credit card is actually quite phenomenal. I am really quite happy with it, I have not had any reason to complain about it whatsoever. The $100 sign up bonus was a very good deal, and the cash back rewards in general are excellent as well. I love being able to use my own image on the card, also. In addition, the customer service for Capital One is wonderful â€“ I had an issue with transferring my reward points and they fixed it immediately. I would recommend this card to anyone who was considering getting a new credit card. All in all, I have not found any issues with this card whatsoever.

name: RASHAD CAMPBELL
review: I have been a Citibank customer for over four years now. I really like this bank and it took me a long time to find a bank that fits my need. They’re many pros to the Citibank. I love their customer service. Any problem I had with the bank always been resolved in my best interest.  I've had insufficient funds and numerous other fees waived just by giving them a call. My local branch also has the best employees and they’re never crowded when I enter. Bank lines go fast inside the bank and in drive through service. I must state that I do have one con which doesn’t affect my overall opinion of this bank, which is location. In my city there’s a select few branch locations. I have to drive 12 miles to my closest bank passing numerous banks in the process. I use Citibank’s online banking to counter those problems. Overall this bank is great and I suggest this bank to everyone.

name: Margie Cole
review: I actually think airline credit cards like the Citi Platinum Select / AAdvantage Visa Signature Credit Card are some of the hardest cards to compare because so much depends on how much the miles are worth upon redemption and what each individual’s travel habits are.  In general though, I can tell you that you should only get an airline card if you regularly fly and a AAdvantage Card if you regularly fly American Airlines or one of its partners.  A rewards card is supposed to help you save concistently, not maybe once and a while, and if you save up a bunch of miles like a squirrel preppin for winter, you might wake up one day to find that stash depleted by hawkish credit card company that now requires more for the same rewards.  Anyway, here are what I see as being the pros and cons of the Citi Platinim Select AAdvantage Visa Card (I guess you could say the length of its name is one con!):Pros-	Initial Bonus:  Anytime you can get a whole heap of free miles is a good thing.  When you get about enough for a free roundtrip flight to the Caribbean, as the Citi AAdvantage Visa Card provides, it’s even better.-	No First Year Annual Fee:  You get a lot of value in the first year without having to pay.  And even when you do start to pay in the second year, you get a $100 discount each year for American Airlines flights.-	Anniversary bonus: Had to list that $100 bonus as its own pro in case someone missed it above.-	Miles refund:  You get 10% of your annually redeemed miles back, which is another reason why only frequent flyers should get the AAdvantage Visa Signature Card.Cons-	Ongoing rewards:  Double miles on AA purchases and one on every dollar you spend on everything else isn’t great.-	Annual fee:  You’d rather not see an annual fee, but its wiped out by the cardholder anniversary present, so it’s not that big a deal.-	Priority boarding and in flight discounts aren’t rewally anything to write home about, especially since youll just have to sit on the plane longer and in flight purchases tend to be fairly expensive already.Ultimately, the Citi Platinum Select / AAdvantage Visa Signature Credit Card is a decent card and makes for a good option for AA customers, but if you’ve got a different airline of choice or have other expenses that are bigger than travel (like gas and groceries) I’d get a card that matches one of them.  For example, the PenFed Platinum Card gives you 5% cash back on gas and the Blue Cash Preferred from Amex offers 6% cash back at supermarkets, 3% at gas stations and department stores, and 1% on everything else.  The Chase Sapphire Preferred also offers a $500 initial bonus, so that’s also something to consider.

name: Margie Cole
review: I don’t really see what’s so prestigious about spending $500 on a credit card, but I guess me and Citi have different ideas of what prestige is since that’s what the Citi ThankYou Presitge Card charges.  Unless this card offers some awesome rewards or low interest, Citi would certainly have to give you a big ole ThankYou for opening it. Pros-	To be frank, I don’t see the Citi Thank You Prestige Card having any positives, so bring on the cons…like a prison break.Cons-	Annual Fee:  The annual fee is an obvious drawback.  No one wants to pay $500 for something they can get for free unless there’s something awesome that sets it apart.-	Ongoing Rewards:  You only get between 1 and 1.3 points per dollar spent?  Camon, that’s nothing.  I could just open the Cap One cash Rewards card and get 1.5% cash back on all purchases.-	Discount flights:  The discounts the Citi Thank You Prestige offers aren’t really benefits since you have to book travel through Citi’s travel partners, who probably don’t have the lowest airfare prices you can find.So in conclusion stay away from the ThankYou Prestige Citicard.  In fact, I wouldn’t get any of the Thank You cards from Citi since there always seems to be a competitor’s card that does what these cards do but better.

name: Joe Weider
review: We as consumers must not have done very much for Citi lately because their thank you seems to be a bit lacking.  I mean 0% for 15 months on purchases and balance transfers is pretty good, but Citi itself offers three different cards that give you 0% on both for 18 months.  And if you want a really good balance transfer card, you’ll probably opt for the No Balance Transfer Fee Slate Card from Chase, which offers 0% for 15 months.  Moving on to rewards, the Citi Thank You Credit Card gives you 1 point per dollar spent across all purchases, which isn’t competitive to say the least.  This ThankYou Citicard, which requires excellent credit for approval by the way, doesn’t offer an initial bonus either.  So semi long story short, I wouldn’t open the Citi ThankYou Card.What would I get?  Well, my favorite cards are probably the aforementioned Slate Card, the Chase Sapphire Card ($500 travel oriented initial bonus), the Citi Platinum Select MasterCard and Diamond Preferred Card (0% for 18 months), and the Blue Cash Preferred from American Express (great everyday rewards).  If you get the right ones of these for your needs, youre in a much better situation than if you get this Citi ThankYou Card.  (Note:  There are a few different Citi ThankYou Cards, and while the others offer some value via modest initial bonuses, they aren’t too great either).

name: Won Lee
review:
WalletHub my favorite 2 banks to do business with are chase and amex. It used to be amex #1 and then chase #2,  but now they flipflopped. Chase really goes out of their way to make your experience better, and their customer service reps are trained so well.  Compare to that, my experience with cap1, barclay, BoA and US banks have not been as stellar.  I say not stellar only because i have tasted what chase and amex offer.  

friendly customer rep
consideration for your argument, rather than flat NO. 
frequent management level personnel contacting you on experience, and should you respond by saying you had negative ones, they will attempt to fix whatever went wrong. 

citi, on the other hand, is middle. They have some really lucrative offers and benefits, but their rep isn't as well trained as chase and amex.  citi, however, are training their CR to offer retention bonuses left and right, which amex and chase do not do as often.

name: Margie Cole
review: Who would get the Citi ThankYou Premier Credit Card offering $150 in gift cards when there’s one offering $250?  That’s what first came to my mind when I saw the two different Thank You Premier Citicards, and I bet this confuses a lot of other people as well.  To understand the differences between these two offers, you gotta dig a bit deeper than their names, I found.How they’re the same.Both the $150 gift card Citi Thank You Premier Card and the $250 version require excellent credit and don’t have annual fees.  Neither offers low introductory interest rates (there are three Citicards that offer 0% on both purchases and transfers for 18 months if that’s what you’re after though).  Both have 12.99% - 22.99% APRs, and they’re both obviously Citi ThankYou Premier Cards.  That’s where the similarities end.How they differ.Obviously one of these Citi Thank You Premier Credit Cards gives an initial bonus worth $100 more, but the question is whether the Citicard with the less lucrative offer makes up for this in any way.  Well, it does by giving you 5 points per dollar at supermarkets, gas stations and drug stores for 12 months before settling into the 1 point per dollar spent across all purchases rewards offered by the other Citi ThankYou Preferred Card.  You therefoe have to ask yourself whether these points would add up to $100 over the course of a year.  If they will, then the Citi ThankYou Premier Credit Card - $150 gift card initial bonus version would be better.Which should you choose.I wouldn’t choose either of these cards.  You can get better intial bonuses from a few other cards (Chase Sapphire Preferred, British Airways Card, etc.) and better everyday rewards (that will last you more than a year) from cards like the Amex Blue Cash Preferred.

name: Margie Cole
review: Man, I want to apply for like every single credit card that offers a semi decent initial bonus.  I could get thousands of dollars that way, quit my job and just trade credit cards all day like some sorta personal finance day trader.  Course that’s not realistic because I don’t really think I could subsist on credit card rewards and you can’t just apply for credit cards left and right since your credit score dips temporarily every time you apply.  After a while you wouldn’t get approved for the cards offering truly lucrative initial bonuses and the plan would be shot.  I guess what I’m saying in a roundabout way is that you shouldn’t just see the Citi ThankYou Preferred Card offering $250 in Gift Cards and jump at the offer.  You should first do a little research to see if there are any better deals out there, especially if the card doesn’t have great ongoing rewards.  That’s what I kept in mind when deciding whether or not to get the $250 gift card Citi ThankYou Preferred Credit Card, and here’s the pro/con list I used:Pros-	No annual fee:  Unless a card offers rewards lucrative enough that it’s still more valuable than the competition even with an annual fee, you should avoid these fees.Cons-	$250 initial bonus:  Since you can get $500 on travel with the Chase Sapphire Preferred and the Hilton Card gives you a bunch of free nights, getting $250 in the form of gift cards isn’t all that great.-	Base rewards:  One point per dollar spent isn’t all that competitive, a number of cards give you 1.5% - 2% cash back on all purchases and others give much more on specific types of purchases.-	0% rates:  The Citi Thank You Premier Credit Card doesn’t offer any, so there’s no interest rate incentive to get it.As you can guess, I didn’t end up getting the ThankYou Premier Citicard.  It just doesn’t stand out relative to the other options I have and it would be a negative value proposition to get it.

name: Margie Cole
review: I’m trying to find a connection between Diamonds, Platinum, and Simplicity.  Does Citi think it’s easy to get diamonds and platinum?  I don’t know, but the Citi Diamond Preferred Card, Platinum Select Card and Simplicity Card all offer basically the same terms.  None offers rewards or charges an annual fee.  All charge 3% balance transfer fees.  All require excellent credit.  And all offer 0% on both purchases and balance transfers for 18 months.  So should you pick one?  Should it be the Diamond Preferred Citicard or another?  How do you choose.  Here’s my pro/con list for the Diamond Preferred Card, I think it will help.Pros-	0% on purchases for 18 months:  A year and a half without having to pay interest on a big purchase?  Yes please.  The same length of time to only pay the minimum each month and let my money EARN interest?  Course.-	No annual fee:  You don’t want to waste money on an annual fee when your trying to save on interest.-	Lowish regular rate:  The Diamond Preferred’s regular APR is 11.99 – 21.99%, depending on your credit standing.  This is the same as the Platinum Select and slightly better than the Simplicity’s 12.99-21.99%.Cons-	3% balance transfer fee:  This can cost you hundred(s) of bucks, so it makes the Citi Diamond Preferred Credit Card ill-suited for balance transfers.-	High credit requirement:  It sorta stinks that you need excellent credit to get the Diamond Preferred Card because the people who you’d think would really need help paying off debt are those with lower scores.When you get down to it, there is really no difference between the Citi Diamond Preferred Card and the Citi Platinum Select Card; either would be a great choice for paying off big purchases.  Neither would be better for balance transfers than the No Balance Transfer Fee Chase Slate Card.

name: Margie Cole
review: It’s quite obvious who the Citi Platinum Select  MasterCard is for. It doesn’t have an annual fee or rewards but does offer a 0% introductory APR for awhile, which makes it pretty much ideal for someone with excellent credit who is either planning a big purchase or wishing to get a lower interest rate for existing credit card debt. Whether or not it’s the best card for this type of person remains to be seen, so her are the pros and cons of picking the Citi Platinum Select Credit Card as I see them.Pros-	0% purchase APR for 18 months: That’s the longest 0% intro period on the market, so it gives you as long as is currently possible to pay off purchase before interest kicks in or even leave your credit card payments in the bank if you find an account with an interest rate better than the best rewards.-	0% balance transfer APR for 18 months: As was the case with purchases, the Platinum Select Citicard’s balance transfer APR is the longest on the market. There is however a downside to this card’s balance transfer terms, as you’ll see in the cons.-	No annual fee: It’d be kind of counterproductive to try to avoid interest costs when paying an annual fee.Cons-	3% balance transfer fee: If you transfer a $5,000 balance for example, this will cost you $150.-	Excellent credit requirement: If you don’t have excellent credit, this could certainly be construed as a con, especially considering the tantalizing terms offered by the Citi Platinum Card.All in all, you can’t do better than the Citi Platinum Select MasterCard or its cousins the Citi Simplicity and the Citi Diamond Preferred (which offer the same terms) if you need as long as possible to pay off an upcoming purchase. If you want to transfer a balance, I’d go with the No Balance Transfer Fee Slate Card from Chase as long as it’s available because it offers 0% for 15 months and does not charge the same expensive transfer fee.Id love to hear others' thoughts on this matter as well!

name: Margie Cole
review: There are so many credit cards out there that makes things difficult, which is what makes the marketing for the Citi Simplicity Card so effective.  People want a simple to use card, and the Simplicity Card’s Name certainly plants the seed in your mind that its that card.  You obviously cant just take it at its name, but luckily deciding whether or not to get it should be fairly simple.  We just need to see what the Citi Simplicity Credit Card offers and how that compares to what the competition offers.  I find that pro/con lists help in doing so.Pros-The Simplicity Citicard offers 0% on purchases and balance transfers for 18 months (tied for longest available).-Does not charge an annual fee.Cons-	The Citi Simplicity Credit Card charges a 3% balance transfer fee.-	It has a higher regular rate than some of its direct competitors.-	No rewardsOverall, the Citi Simplicity is a great credit card, no doubt about it.  But it is slightly beat out by other cards.  For example, if you want 0% for the longest time possible, you’d probably apply for the Citi Diamond Preferred or the Citi Platinum Select because they too give you 0% for 18 months and have lower regular APRs than the Citi Simplicity Card.  Likewise, if you would rather sacrifice 0% time for a lower transfer fee, the No Balance Transfer Slate Card from Chase offers 0% for 15 months and doesn’t charge a balance transfer fee.  Finally, if you’re after rewards, the Simplicity Card obviously won’t cut it.  There are a number of good options out there, but some of my favorites are the Chase Sapphire Preferred, Capital One Venture and the Blue Cash Preferred from Amex.

name: Joe Weider
review: Anyone with a car could certainly use a way to save on gas, especially now as the prices are rising to record levels.  You may or may not know it, but a credit card can be a great means of garnering these savings as certain offers give rebates or cash back rates on gas purchases.  One such card is obviously the ExxonMobil Credit Card.  Whether or not you should get this card depends on a few different factors, including obviously what it offers, which we’ll start with in this little review.  The Exxon Mobil Credit Card gets you $0.15 off each gallon of each gallon of gas you purchase at Exxon Mobil Stations.  It also gives you UP TO 2% cash back on all other purchases.  What that means is the Exxon Mobil Card gives you 0.5% on annual non-gas purchases up to $999, 1% on purchases above $1,000 up to $5,999, 2% on purchases above $5,999 up to $10,000, and 1% on all purchases above that.  Those non-gas cash back rates are ok, but the draw of the Exxon Mobil Credit Card is definitely the gas rebate that it provides.  To put it in percentage terms (it’s confusing that credit card companies do not express their rewards in the same manner -  doing so makes the bad offers seem better, I suppose), the Exxon Credit Card gives you 4.1% off each gallon of ExxonMobil gas you buy.Now, I said we’d get to the other factors at play in picking the right gas credit card and here we go.  First of all, only people who ONLY get their gas at ExxonMobil should get the Exxon Mobil Rewards Card.  People who don’t wouldn’t be able to get the value they want from it.  Sure, you could switch to getting your gas only at Exxon stations, but unless that’s extremely convenient, such a change probably won’t last.  Another factor to consider is what other gas rewards cards offer. If you have a station of choice other than Exxon Mobil, it’s a good idea to check out how it’s co-branded credit card compares to the Exxon Card.  People who go to various stations should check out generic gas rewards cards, which are basically cash back cards that offer higher rewards earning rates on gas purchases.  Some of the most interesting offers come from the Pentagon Federal Credit Union.  They offer 5% off gas purchases anywhere.  The Blue Cash Everyday Card from American Express is also a good deal because in addition to 2% off gas station and department store purchases, it gives you 3% off at supermarkets and 1% everywhere else.

name: Joe Weider
review: There are a ton of rewards credit cards out there and it can be difficult to figure out which will pad your wallet the most.  No I’m not talking about a squishy card that’s comfortable to sit on, rather a card that will maximize your free cash.  Branding doesn’t provide much of a clue because it seems like every card has “gold” or “platinum” in its name.  Instead you gotta take a look at exactly what a card offers and figure out its actual practical effect using past months’ spending.  Well, the Citi Dividend Platinum Select Visa Card -- $100 cash back obviously offers a $100 cash back bonus (in return for spending at least $500 in the first three months), but it also offers 5% cash back on purchase categories that change quarterly (which you have to sign up for each quarter) and 1% cash back on everything else.  In terms of rates, the Citi Dividend Platinum Card offers 0% on purchases and transfers for 12 months.  Might seem pretty darn good, but when you consider that you need excellent credit to get Dividend Platinium Citicard, it’s really not.  See, excellent credit can get you hundreds (plural) of dollars in free money or as long as 18 months with 0%.  What about both?  You shouldn’t try to get an all-around credit card because doing so will likely mean sacrificing all-aound.  If a credit card excels in one respect, it usually comes up short in others.  If it doesn’t excel in any area, there are obviously better cards to get.  So instead of opening the Citi Dividend Platinum Select Visa, either focus on getting the best possible card for your main need (e.g. rewards or low interest) or two cards that together provide the best possible terms attainable.As far as rewards go, if youre looking for a card for ongoing use, you should get one with rewards matching your spending habits.  This obviously depends on the individual, but some good cards to start with are the Blue Cash Everyday and Blue Cash Preferred from Amex.  If you want a great initial balance, go for the Chase Sapphire Preferred.  If you want the longest possible 0% rate, there are three citicards offering it for 18 months.  Strategically opening one or a couple of these cards in conjunction will provide more benefit than the Citi Dividend Platinum Select - $100 cash bonus card.

name: Joe Weider
review: While the Citi Platinum Select Credit Card does not offer rewards, it more than makes up for that with its introductory interest rates.  The Platinum Card is one of three Citicards that offers 0% on purchases as well as balance transfers for 21 months (along with the Citi Simplicity and Diamond Preferred Cards).  Since 21 months is the longest 0% term available, the obvious question is does the Citi Platinum Select MasterCard differentiate itself at all from its cousins, so to speak, or does it make no difference which offer you choose?  Well, the Platinum Select Citicard is exactly the same as the Diamond Preferred Card, both have 11.99% - 21.99% (V) APRs and no annual fee.  The Simplicity Card only differs in that it has a 12.99% - 21.99% (V) APR. Ok, but who are these cards right for?  Both the Citi Platinum Card or the Diamond Preferred would be extremely helpful for people who need to lower the cost of debt, either an existing balance or an upcoming big-ticket purchase.  There is another interesting application for these cards as well, however.  If your bank account, gives you a lucrative interest rate, you could simply make minimum payments over the first 21 months with your card, leaving the rest of your would be payments to grow in the bank for longer.  Whether this makes sense obviously depends on your interest rate and the rewards you could get from other cards.  Keep in mind that a card like the Discover More Card offers 0% for 15 months and gives you rewards, which means that you could earn both interest and rewards revenue if you use it for the approach laid out above.

name: Joe Weider
review: I’ll tell ya what, no matter how good the Citi Diamond Preferred Card is, I’d “prefer” and actual “diamond.”  It’s hard to imagine anyone who wouldn’t, so let’s move past that premise to what the Diamond Preferred Citi Card does and does not offer.  First of all, it doesn’t have rewards (a bad thing) or annual fees (a good thing).  It does, however, offer a 0% APR for purchases and balance transfers for 21 months.  That means you could buy a diamond (or another big-ticket item) with the Citi Diamond Preferred Credit Card and have the opportunity to pay for it interest free.  You could also leave your would be credit card payments in the bank for 21 months, so that you can earn the good kind of interest (make sure to still make minimum payments if you take this approach).  But you could not leave your payments in the bank while earning rewards on the purchases you make with the Diamond Preferred Card and in doing so double your free money because the Diamond Preferred Card doesn’t offer rewards.  The Discover More Card offers the best chance to do this because it has 0% on purchases and transfers for 21 months as well as cash back rewards on every purchase.  Whether you get the More Card or the Citibank Diamond Preferred seems depends on your ability to pay your bills in the 0% time allotted and how your bank account’s interest rate compares to the More Card’s rewards earning rate (i.e. whether you would get more from 21 months of 0% or 15 months with rewards).Ultimately, while the Citi Diamond Preferred Card is not the card to get if you want rewards, it is one of the best offers out there for people looking for lower interest costs.  It’s not too unique though in the sense that the Citi Simplicity and Platinum Select Cards both offer 0% for 21 months as well (the Simplicity Card offers a slightly higher regular interest rate range than the other two).

name: Joe Weider
review: Much of college is about promise and potential, building knowledge and improving career prospects.  All of these things are forward-looking, so it’s no wonder why Citi calls its student credit card the Citi Forward Card for College Students; it leads you to think that this is the card that will leave you best set up for a bright future.  Whether this is just clever branding remains to be seen though.  The Citi Forward College Student Credit Card does not have an annual fee, which means it passes the first test for student credit cards.  (Credit building is the main reason to have a student credit card and having no annual fee helps you build credit as inexpensively as possible, especially since you can build credit without actually using your card to make purchases). The next thing most students will want to know is what rewards the Citi Forward Card offers.  Well, it gives you 1,000 bonus points when you sign up for paperless statements during the first three months as well as 100 bonus points each month you pay on time and stay under your balance.  You should be able to garner all 2,200 of these bonus points since you’re likely more comfortable with digital account management and you’d have to opt-in for the ability to exceed your limit anyway (should not do so unless you trust yourself to go over-limit only in emergencies).  You also get 5 points for each dollar you spend at restaurants and on books, music, and movies.  Overall, this rewards structure is good in the sense that it rewards proper account management and gives you points on some of a college student’s biggest expenses.  Whether it offers the best rewards depends on how much you will use your credit card.  If you will use your card a lot and for all kinds of purchases, something like the Capital One Journey Card, which provides 1.25% cash back on all purchases might be better.  If you plan on using your card minimally and only for food, entertainment and books, for example, then Citi’s Student Forward Card could provide could provide more benefit in bonus points alone than you’d get via an entire year using a different student card.  The Discover Open Road Card is a good option for commuters since it gives you 2% cash back on the first $250 you spend on gas and at restaurants each month as well as 1% on everything else.You might be thinking that I forgot about rates.  I didn’t, but they are generally not as important as other card features given that students should not be spending more than they can afford to pay.  The Citi Forward Card for College Students does offer 0% on purchases for seven months though, which makes it middle of the road in the student category.  The Discover Open Road Card offers 0% on purchases for the longest period of time – 9 months.

name: Joe Weider
review: Which is it, a City Business or a World Business.  They really need to figure that out.  Bad attempts at humor aside though, the CitiBusiness World MasterCard will be one of the primary choices for anyone looking for a business credit card due to the facts that Citi is a large, recognizable credit card company and the “World” in the card’s name connotes the ability to make transactions overseas without incurring foreign transaction fees.  Whether these clues will actually lead you to the right credit card for business is another story though, one which requires a closer look to determine the ending.  First of all, the Citi Business World MasterCard offers 10,000 bonus points for spending at least $300 in the first three months, and these points are redeemable for a $100 gift card.  You also get 3 ThankYou points for every dollar spent on office supplies and professional services and one point per dollar spent on everything else.  You can redeem ThankYou points for merchandise, travel rewards, gift cards, cash and more but the number of points needed for different rewards is what actually matters.  Well, with 8,000 points  you can get $50.  In other words, while you get to redeem your initial bonus points at a rate of 1%, yiu get less than that with the points you earn on an ongoing basis. Oh, and the Business World MasterCard from Citi DOES have a foreign transaction fee of 3% which begs the question of what is so worldly about the card to begin with.Regardless, you’re going to need some alternatives because the Citi Business MasterCard is not rewarding enough to cut it.  If you crave simplicity the obvious choice is the Capital One Spark Cash for Business since it offers 2% cash back across all purchases.  Someone wanting to maximize their initial benefit might like the Ink Bold with Ultimate Rewards since it offers 50,000 bonus points, redeemable for $500 cash or $625 in travel.  Either way its important to note that the best business credit card stratrgy these days is to use a rewards business credit card (like the CitiBusiness World MasterCard and the other cards mentioned previously) for everyday purchases and a 0% consumer credit card for funding.  This will get you the best card rates and debt stability and will not cause you to sacrifice liability protection.

name: Joe Weider
review: Everytime gas prices rise, interest in gas credit cards does as well.  In general you should only get a gas credit card if gas is one of your biggest expenses and a gas card tied to a particular chain if you ONLY get gas at its locations.  So if you are either a loyal Shell customer or live in an area that enables you to cast your allegiances with one of many stations, you may be interested in the Shell Credit Card.  The Shell Card, which requires good or excellent credit for approval, does not have an annual fee but does offer a 10 cents/gallon credit for the first 100 gallons of Shell gasoline you purchase each month following a month in which you made at least $500 in qualifying purchases.  When you spend $1,000-$2,499.99, you get 15 cents/gal. and when you spend over $2,499.99 you get 20 cents off per gallon. The Shell Card obviously does not have the most straightforward rewards program ever devised (and I would not spend more than you would ordinarily in order to get to a higher rewards earning level) but it could be fairly lucrative one, depending on the price of gas and what “qualifying purchases” are.  A quick look at the Shell site will tell you that qualifying purchases are those made for personal, family or household reasons, so its only business expenses that don’t count.  For the week of 01/09/12, regular gas costs an average of 3.382/gal. nationwide.  The 10 cent per gallon rebate would therefore equate to about 3% cash back on 100 gallons of Shell gas.  For someone who fills up once a week and puts say 14 gallons of gas in their car each time, the Shell Credit Card would save about $5.60 each month.  For comparison sake, the Exxon Credit Card gives you 15 cents per gallon rebates that are not constrained by gallon limits.  It also gives you up to 2% cash back on everything else you buy each year.  The BP Credit Card also gives you 10% off BP gas for the first 60 days and 5% after that as well as attractive cash back rates on other purchase categories.  The Blue Cash Everyday Credit Card offers 3% cash back at supermarkets, 2% at any gas station or grocery store and 1% on everything else.  This makes it clear that the Shell Credit Card is competitive but that there are also other more attractive offers out there.  If you can easily get your gas from either Exxon or BP, their credit cards would be more lucrative (The Shell Card beats the Exxon Card for heavy spenders though).  If you want the freedom to get gas anywhere but still earn rewards on it and other types of purchases then the Blue Cash Card would be better.  Ultimately, only people who can only get gas at Shell Stations should get the Shell Credit Card and even they should think about whether a gas oriented cash back card like the Blue Cash would better meet their needs.

name: Joe Weider
review: Just because you are an executive or one of the world’s elite (or you just want to be) doesn’t mean you have to pay like it.  That’s why I am immediately dubious of the Citi ExecutiveSM / AAdvantage World EliteTM MasterCard and its $450 annual fee.  A credit card better offer an awful lot to warrant such a high fee and most people don’t have hundreds of dollars to spend on a credit card’s membership fee.  We’ll give the Citi Executive AAdvantage World Elite MasterCard a fair shake though.  It offers 25,000 bonus miles after you spend $1,000 during the first four months, 10,000 elite status miles from American Airlines each year you spend $40k on it, 2 miles per dollar spent through AA, 1 mile per dollar on everything else, priority boarding and check in, and Admiral’s Club access for you and immediate family.  Plenty of cards offer initial bonuses in the 25k mile range and base rewards earning rates in the 2 mile/$1 spent range, so these aspects of the Citi Executive AAdvantage World Elite MasterCard Credit Card do not validate its cost.  The most eye catching attributes would instead have to be the Elite Status miles and the Admiral’s Club access.  But do these things make the card worth it?  Admiral’s Club memberships for a married couple range from $525 to $825/yr. depending on their status level, so if you travel a lot and value club access, then the Citi Executive AAdvantage World Elite MasterCard would seem to be worth it.Not everyone fits that description though, and they need cheaper alternatives.  The Citi® Platinum Select® / AAdvantage® World MasterCard® Credit Card for one offers more bonus miles than the Executive AAdvantage World Elite MasterCard and does not have a first year annual fee ($85 after that).  The Chase Sapphire Preferred Card offers $625 in travel as an initial bonus and doesn’t have an annual fee either ($95 after that).  The Capital One Venture Card is basically a 2% cash back travel oriented rewards card and also doesn’t have an annual fee in the first year ($59 after that).  Any of these would be rewarding for a frequent traveler, all would be significantly cheaper than the Executive AAdvantage World Elite MasterCard from Citi.

name: Joe Weider
review: If people all over had the Citi ThankYou Prestige Credit Card, you know what it would be like?  Prestige Worldwide.  Sounds so cool, huh?  Almost like a lightning bolt hit…oh, nevermind.  The first thing one notices about the Citi ThankYou Prestige Credit Card is its $500 annual fee.  This should immediately tell you that it is card for people with very high income who want to pay extra for the best rewards.  If it doesn’t have extremely attractive rewards, at least rewards that would make a $500 fee understandable, then it will be clear that the Citi ThankYou Prestige Card is one to be avoided.  To get right to it, this card offers 1.3 points for every dollar you spend on or at supermarkets, drug stores, gas stations, commuter transportation, and parking merchants.  (The last two you don’t really see everyday).  You also get 1 point per dollar spent on everything else.  Things like discounts on flights purchased through Citi aren’t really benefits at all, since higher prices will likely counteract any savings.These rewards are by no means worth it.  So like the Visa Black Card, the Citi ThankYou Prestige Credit Card is just an overpriced, underwhelming credit card option.   Alternatives are in order then.  Two of my favorite rewards cards currently on the market are the Blue Cash Everyday from Amex (3% cash back at supermarkets, 2% at gas stations and department stores, 1% on everything else, a $100 initial bonus, and no annual fee) and the Chase Sapphire Preferred ($500-625 initial bonus, 2 points per dollar spent on travel and dining, 1 point on everything else, no annual fee in the first year, $95/yr. after that).  Both of these cards certainly outperform the no so prestigious Citi ThankYou Prestige Credit Card.

name: William L
review: The $250 in air credits pay for half don’t forget

name: Susan Emigh
review: I can't believe how difficult it is for a Canadian to pay up his/her Brooks Brothers account! You have to be able to write a cheque from a U.S. bank...and how many of us have that! Advice: Canadians, do NOT get a Brooks Brothers card, ever!

name: Joe Weider
review: Citi certainly appears to be trend surfing these days.  I mean it’s currently popular to offer initial rewards bonuses to new customers who open certain cards and spend a certain amount in the first few months.  Everybody’s doing it.  I also read somewhere that gift cards are the most popular gift like six years running.  The Citi ThankYou Premier Card - $100 gift card combines those two things, giving you an initial rewards bonus in the form of a $100 gift card after you spend $500 in the first three months.  But don’t jump at the chance to get this card before you know what else it offers and what else is on the market for someone with excellent credit.  This Citi ThankYou Card also offers 5 points for every dollar spent at gas stations, supermarkets and drug stores for the first year of use, 1 point on every dollar spent after that, and 0% on purchases and balance transfers for 12 months.There are actually better options for basically every feature of the Citi ThankYou Premier Card.  Its $100 initial bonus is easily bested by its brother, the Citi ThankYou Premier Credit Card - $500 in gift cards, which requires you to spend $2,500 in the first three months in order to get this higher bonus.  The Blue Cash Everyday from American Express, which offers 3% cash back at supermarkets, 2% at gas stations and department stores, and 1% on everything else, has better rewards than the $100 version of the Citi ThankYou Credit Card.  The Citi Simplicity Card, with its 0% on purchases and transfers for 21 months, has better introductory rates.  Hey, at least the Citi ThankYou Premier Card - $100 gift card offer is polite.

name: Joe Weider
review: Ok, Christmas is coming up and for many people that means figuring out how to make our money go as far as possible.  One common way to do so is opening a store card or a credit card affiliated with a certain retailer in order to get extra savings on purchases you are likely to make anyway.  If you or someone you plan on giving gifts to likes Brooks Brothers, you may come across this Brooks Brothers Credit Card, and the question you will inevitably ask is whether it is worth applying for.  The Brooks Brothers Credit Card is offered by GE Money and requires good to excellent credit for approval.  So if you don’t have at least good credit you can forget about getting it, at least for the moment.  If you have upper echelon credit history, you need to determine how the Brooks Brothers Credit Card’s rewards stack up against other cards on the market.  This card gets you 15% off on your first Brooks Brothers purchase, 4 points for every dollar you spend at Brooks Bros. and1 point for every dollar spent elsewhere.  Since Brooks Brothers rewards points automatically translate into a $20 gift card when you compile 20,000 of them, at best, you get $20 for every $5,000 you spend at the store. I know prices are high at Brooks Brothers, but that’s really not much bang for your buck.  Let’s say you decide to take advantage of the store’s 2 suits for $1599 deal this Christmas, you’ll save almost $240 and will need to spend about $3400 more to get an additional $20 off.  $240 and change is nothing to sneeze at, but the truth is that you can do better than what the Brooks Brothers GE Money Credit Card offers.If you decide to apply for the Chase Saphirre Preferred Credit card for instance, you get a $500 cash initial bonus after spending $3,000 in the first three months.  You’d easily be able to meet this threshold if you buy a couple suits at Brooks Bros. for the holidays and would then have more money to replenish your bank account than the Brooks Brothers Credit Card would provide, you’d just have to wait a bit longer to get it.  So my advice is to pass on the Brooks Brothers Credit Card because, ironically enough, a different credit card could help save you more on Brooks Brothers purchases.

name: Joe Weider
review: Citi is saying Thank You for keeping up your excellent credit throughout the recession by offering you $250 in gift cards after you spend $2,000 during the first three months with the Citi ThankYou Preferred Card.  Come to think of it they’re probably saying Thank You for spending that much too and giving them the interchange fees that result, but hey.  A lot of credit card companies are offering these initial rewards bonuses for new customers, and since gift cards are established as the most popular presents (I don’t really know what this says about us), the Citi ThankYou Preferred’s bonus might seem pretty darn handy.  But if you are opening a new credit card with just the initial bonus in mind you can do better believe it or not.  The Chase Sapphire Preferred would be a good card to target because it gives you either $625 in airline and hotel expenses or $500 cash.  If you want a combo of a good bonus and ongoing rewards, it bears seeing what else the Citi ThankYou Preferred Card offers.  Not too much it seems.  Just 1 point per $1 spent and an “anniversary bonus” whatever that means.  The ThankYou Premier Card doesn’t have a low introductory interest rate either.  So I’d probably say that you should definitely explore other options before applying for this Citi Premier Card.  I’d recommend the Capital One Venture Card, the Sapphire Card mentioned before and the version of the Citi ThankYou Premier Card that offers $500 in gift cards.  Yeah, there are apparently two of these babies.  The difference between them (besides the gift card bonus amount obviously) is that the version with the lower bonus does not have an annual fee ever and the one with the higher bonus has a $125 fee beginning in the second year.  I’d say thanks but no thanks to the $250 version of the Citi ThankYou Premier Card as a result and why thank you to either the version with a better bonus or one of the other cards mentioned in this little review.

name: Joe Weider
review: It’s officially gift card season, so you might be tempted to open the Citi ThankYou Premier Card, as it offers an initial bonus of $500 in gift cards after you spend $2,500 during the first three months.  But before you pull the trigger and submit an application, you should know exactly what else this card offers as well as how it ranks among the competition.  The only really worthwhile things that the Citi ThankYou Premier Credit Card offers is 1.2 points per dollar spent at gas stations, supermarkets, drug stores, and commuter transportation and parking merchants and 1 point per dollar spent on everything else.  The free annual companion airline ticket and 15% discounts on air travel you get when booking through Sprint Incentives probably won’t be a great deal because Sprint Inventive fares are bound to be much higher than discount comparison sites like Expedia and Kayak.As a result, I’d have to say that there are better choices than the Citi ThankYou Card out there if you’re looking to get a new credit card this holiday season.  I mean the Chase Sapphire Preferred is offering an initial bonus worth $500 - $625, depending on how you choose to redeem the bonus points you get for spending $3,000 in the first three months.  The Capital One Cash Credit Card offers 1.5% cash back across all purchases.  The Capital One Venture Card is basically a travel-oriented 2% cash back card.  Like the ThankYou Card from Citi, none of these cards charge membership fees in the first year.  Unlike the Citi ThankYou Card, these cards all have membership fees in subsequent years that are less than $125.  I’d therefore have to recommend saying ThankYou but no ThankYou about the ThankYou Premier Card.

name: Joe Weider
review: Are you a forward thinker?  By that I, of course, mean are you thinking about opening the Citi Forward Card?  If so, you should be well aware of exactly what it offers, how practically attractive these offerings are, and how they stack up to the rest of the above-average credit card market.  I fancy myself as somewhat of an amateur credit card expert, so here’s my two cents on this card; I hope it helps.In terms of rewards, the Citi Forward Credit Card offers 10,000 bonus points for spending $650 and signing up for paperless statements within the first three months.  This initial rewards bonus is redeemable for $100 in gift cards.  You also get 5 points per dollar spent at restaurants and on entertainment (i.e. books, movies, and music) as well as 1 point per dollar spent on everything else.  In terms of interest rates, the Forward Card offers 0% on purchases for seven months and 0% on balance transfers for 12 months (3% balance transfer fee).  After these intro rates expire, a 12.99% - 22.99% variable interest rate kicks in.  Which end of the spectrum you regular interest rate ends up being on is determined by your credit standing.Ultimately, this card does a little bit of everything pretty well, but nothing is exceptional.  If you are interested in a card with a good initial bonus, the Chase Sapphire Preferred is a better option.  If you need an everyday rewards card, I’d argue that the Capital One Venture Card is better than the Citi Forward Card because it is basically a 2% cash back card if you redeem for any travel related purchase and it also has a $100 initial rewards bonus.  Alternatively, if you don’t travel much, a card like the Capital One Cash Rewards Credit Card offers 1.5% across all purchases and would probably prove more lucrative than the Citi Forward Card because most people’s spending exceeds the bounds of restaurant and entertainment purchases.  Finally, if you are interested in a low introductory interest rate, then the Citi Simplicity Card is the way to go, since it offers 0% on purchases and transfers for 21 months.  So, you probably should not move forward with the Citi Forward Credit Card.

name: Joe Weider
review: Shortly after the new iPhone dropped, I reviewed the AT&T Universal Savings Platinum Credit Card, and it just occurred to me that I should take a look at what its business cousin, the AT&T Universal Business Credit Card, has to offer.  The AT&T Universal Business Card is for small business owners who have good or excellent personal credit scores (very important to realize).  It’s a Citicard on the Visa network and doesn’t have an annual fee, but you’re obviously going to be most interested in the rewards it does have.  This card offers 5 Citi ThankYou points for each dollar you charge on AT&T-related purchases, 3 points for purchases made through certain office suppliers, gas stations and professional services companies, and 1 point on everything else.  You might be wondering what “certain” means, and according to the card’s rewards program details, “Office supply merchants are defined as stand-alone merchants that primarily sell stationery and office supplies for business consumption. Gas stations are defined as stand-alone merchants that primarily sell vehicle fuel for consumer use. Professional services are defined as standalone tax preparation, accounting, bookkeeping, and legal services providers that provide their respective services to businesses.”  Apparently warehouse clubs, discount stores and convenience stores don’t count.The above might all seem like a lot to keep track of and for that exact reason, I’d stay away from the AT&T Universal Business Credit Card.  I’m not a small business owner, but I know a few people who are and they have more than enough to worry about without fussing over what types of purchases qualify for X or Y amount of rewards.  If I had to choose, I’d probably go with the Capital One cash business credit card over the AT&T business credit card cause it gives you 2% on all purchases, making it a whole lot simpler.

name: Joe Weider
review: The Hilton ladies have garnered quite a bit of attention throughout the years, but what about a different type of Hilton plastic (get it, they’ve probably had work done), the Citi Hilton HHonors Credit Card?  What does it have to offer the world?  For starters, this Visa card which requires at least good credit of applicants offers an initial rewards bonus of 40,000 Hilton HHonors points.  You get these after spending at least $1k during the first four months you have the Citi Hilton Credit Card.  That’s pretty good, but it also isn’t uncommon for affinity rewards cards these days.  The Citi Hilton HHonors Credit Card also has a base rewards structure that provides 6 HHonors points for each dollar spent at Hilton Hotels; 3 points for each dollar spent on supermarket, drugstore and gas station purchases; and 2 points per $1 on everything else.  Finally, you automatically have Hilton HHonors Silver Status as a Citi Hilton Credit Card holder.This begs the question of how many points it takes to get a free night and what Silver Status scores you.  Well, 40,000 points gets you one free night in a really nice Hilton Hotel and 3 nights in one of the company’s, and Silver Status gets you 15% more base points, free access to spas and fitness centers at Hilton hotels and 2 complimentary bottles of water at certain Hilton hotels [I don’t know about you, but those bottles sealed the deal for me ;) ].Before wrapping up this look at the Citi Hilton Credit Card it is important to note that like the Hilton twins, there is also more than one Hilton Credit Card.  In addition to the Citi Hilton Card, a Hilton HHonors Surpass Credit Card is also available.  This card offers slightly better rewards, but has a $75 annual fee.  In case I didn’t mention it, the Hilton Citicard does not have an annual membership fee.

name: Joe Weider
review: We all know that Best Buy Gift Cards will be a popular gift this holiday season, but what about the Best Buy Credit Card?  Could it also play an important role in your holiday spending?  Well, this store card offers 2 points per $1 spent at Best Buy and Best Buy.com.  250 points gets you a $5 gift card, so for every $125 you spend at Best Buy, the Best Buy Credit Card saves you $5.  That makes the Best Buy card essentially a 4% cash back credit card on store purchases, which is pretty good if you plan on doing most of your shopping at Best Buy.  Some interesting financing offers are also part of the Best Buy Credit Card.  If you pay down purchases totaling $149 – $429 within 6 months, you won’t be charged interest.  If you pay down those totaling $429 - $899 within 12 months, there’s no interest.  And the same thing is true if you pay down purchases of $899 and up within 18 months.   Given that the holiday season is the busiest shopping time of the year and electronics are popular gifts, these deals could be helpful in paying down purchases you can’t initially cover with cash.  Still, this card only has value if you are a diehard Best Buy shopper, and no matter your store preferences, I would recommend taking a look at cash back rewards cards and balance transfer cards to see if any provide equal or more value than the Best Buy Credit Card AND allow you to earn your rewards or apply your low interest rate to purchases made at any store.

name: Joe Weider
review: While you kind of expect an interesting rewards structure from gas credit cards, you’d hope that the terms would be somewhat better than what the CITGO Credit Card is offering.  Sure, you get 4% rebates on “qualifying” Citgo purchases, but c’mon, only 0.5% on all other annual purchases under $5,000 and 1% on everything above that mark?  That might not seem so bad until you consider that the BP Credit Card for example gives you 10% on BP purchases, 4% on travel and dining and 2% on the rest for 60 days, and 5%, 2% and 1% after that.  You’re probably not going to get the BP Credit Card instead of the CITGO Card, since they are both affiliated gas credit cards and you pretty much have to only get gas at your affiliated card’s station to make it worth it. The comparison just shows that CITGO isn’t necessarily as competitive as you’d like with its competitors and if you are a CITGO customer, getting the CITGO credit card might not be as big of a no brainer as you thought.  I mean, there are cards out there that give you 1.5% CASH BACK across ALL purchases (2% if you’re a small business owner).

name: Joe Weider
review: The new iPhone is getting a lot of buzz these days, and since it is still pretty expensive, I thought I’d take a look at some credit cards to see if any were offering initial bonuses that could help consumers afford the phone.  I started by looking at the card bearing the name of one of the main cell networks carrying the iPhone:  the AT&T Universal Savings Platinum Credit Card.  This AT&T credit card--which is issued by Citibank, offered on the MasterCard network, and requires good or excellent credit for approval—unfortunately does not offer an initial rewards bonus.  What it does have is a rather interesting rewards structure.  Instead of providing a set cash back rate across all purchases with potentially better rewards on certain spending categories, the AT&T Universal Savings Platinum Credit Card offers tiered rewards.  Each month, you get 0.5% cash back for purchases up to $250 spent, 1% between $250 and $750, and 1.5% above $750.  Considering that the Capital One Cash credit card offers 1.5% on all purchases, regardless of how much you spend, what the AT&T card has to offer in terms of rewards isn’t all that good.  Neither card, by the way, has an annual fee.  Interestingly, the AT&T Universal Savings Platinum Credit Card does have a pretty attractive balance transfer offer:  0% on transfers for 15 months with a 3% balance transfer fee.  While there are at least nine other cards currently on the market offering 0% for at least that long (some as long as 21 months) at least the AT&T card is in the upper echelon.  Still, I wouldn’t suggest going into debt to buy the iPhone and then transferring your balance to this card.  The balance transfer fee makes this costly and not worth the risk, especially since you might not even get approved for a balance transfer.

name: Joe Weider
review: Forget the Great Recession, what happened to the Red Sox over the past month has to be the biggest collapse that we’ve seen in a long while, but as a Yankees fan I’m certainly not complaining.  Instead, I’m trying to save on a flight to Detroit on Oct. 3 (hopefully to see a sweep) as well as (fingers crossed) flights to Tampa or Arlington and any National League City that wants a piece of the 27-time World Series champs.  Since credit cards affiliated with airlines have recently been offering free flights just for signing up and American Airlines serves all of the cities with teams in the playoffs, why not see what their credit card has to offer?  It only seems right to take America’s airline to see America’s baseball team dominate after all.As it turns out, Citi offers a number of cards that are affiliated with American Airlines, and this Citi Gold / AAdvantage World MasterCard Credit Card offers the most lucrative initial bonus—30,000 bonus miles.  Unfortunately, the fact that cardholders only get these cards after spending $750 in the first fourth months makes it of little immediate benefit to me.  But, after checking out a few other cards tied to different airlines, I have learned that these spending requirements are more of the norm than the exception.  The Citi Gold AAdvantage MasterCard actually stacks up pretty well against similar cards.  Only the Continental Airlines Credit Card and the United MileagePlus cards have the potential to offer more lucrative initial bonuses and though the Citi AAdvantage card has a slightly higher APR, its annual fee is $45 less than those charged by these other cards.  So, while I’m not going to apply for this card and you can probably do better if an initial bonus is what you’re after, if you’re an American Airlines frequent flyer, it could be a good addition to your wallet.

name: Joe Weider
review: When it comes to getting a card with a 0% APR I have not found a credit card that can beat the Simplicity Card - 0% for 21 months on both purchases and balance transfers is amazing! For the next 21 months, I am literally tempted to get this credit card, pay the minimum payment, deposit the rest of the money in a high yield savings account and then before the 0% expires pay the card in full (from the money that I have been depositing all along in my savings account). On the other hand, I currently use the Venture Rewards card from Capital One and get 2% cash back on all my purchases so I would have to give that up.  Any other better alternatives?

name: WalletHub
review: Joe - This is an interesting strategy. Based on what you wrote, you obviously have the ability to pay your bill in full every month. Therefore, I suggest that you keep things simple and use your rewards credit card. Besides, I doubt that you can find a savings account that pays much more than 2% - right?
